revision.text:
{{Distinguish|Dictation (disambiguation)}} A '''dication''' is any [[cation]], of general formula X<sup>2+</sup>, formed by the removal of two [[electrons]] from a neutral species.
Diatomic dications corresponding to stable neutral species (e.g. {{chem|H|2|2+}} formed by removal of two electrons from H<sub>2</sub>) often decay quickly into two singly charged particles (H<sup>+</sup>), due to the loss of electrons in bonding molecular orbitals. Energy levels of diatomic dications can be studied with good resolution by measuring the yield of pairs of zero-kinetic-energy electrons from double [[photoionization]] of a molecule as a function of the photoionizing wavelength (threshold photoelectrons coincidence [[spectroscopy]] – TPEsCO). The {{chem|He|2|2+}} dication is kinetically stable.
An example of a stable diatomic dication which is not formed by oxidation of a neutral diatomic molecule is the [[dimercury]] dication {{chem|Hg|2|2+}}. An example of a polyatomic dication is {{chem|S|8|2+}}, formed by oxidation of S<sub>8</sub> and unstable with respect to further oxidisation over time to form SO<sub>2</sub>.
Many organic dications can be detected in [[mass spectrometry]] for example {{chem|CH|4|2+}} (a {{chem|CH|2|2+|·H|2}} complex) and the acetylene dication {{chem|C|2|H|2|2+}}.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Lammertsma |first1=K. |last2=von Ragué Schleyer |first2=P. |last3=Schwarz |first3=H. |date=1989 |title=Organic Dications: Gas Phase Experiments and Theory in Concert |journal=Angew. Chem. Int. Ed. Engl. |volume=28 |pages=1321–1341 |doi=10.1002/anie.198913211}}</ref> The [[adamantane|adamantyl dication]] has been synthesized. [[File:Adamantane dication.png|600px|The adamantane dication]]
==Divalent metals== {{Periodic table (micro) | title=Common element dications | mark=Be, Mg, Ca, Sr, Ba, Ra, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn, Cd, Hg, Sn, Pb }} Some metals are commonly found in the form of dications when in the form of salts, or dissolved in water. Examples include the [[alkaline earth]] metals (Be<sup>2+</sup>, Mg<sup>2+</sup>, Ca<sup>2+</sup>, Sr<sup>2+</sup>, Ba<sup>2+</sup>, Ra<sup>2+</sup>); later [[transition metal]]s (V<sup>2+</sup>, Cr<sup>2+</sup>, Mn<sup>2+</sup>, Fe<sup>2+</sup>, Co<sup>2+</sup>, Ni<sup>2+</sup>, Cu<sup>2+</sup>); [[group 12 element]]s (Zn<sup>2+</sup>, Cd<sup>2+</sup>, Hg<sup>2+</sup>); and the heavy members of the [[carbon group]] (Sn<sup>2+</sup>, Pb<sup>2+</sup>).
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Ions]]

revision.comment: Added free to read link in citations with [[WP:OABOT|OAbot]] #oabot
revision.text:
<!-- Please leave this line alone! --> '''Differential dynamic microscopy''' Differential dynamic microscopy (DDM) is an optical technique that allows performing [[light scattering]] experiments by means of a simple [[optical microscope]].<ref name="cerbino08">{{cite journal | last1 = Cerbino | first1 = R. | last2 = Trappe | first2 = V. | year = 2008 | title = Differential dynamic microscopy: Probing wavevector-dependent dynamics with a microscope | doi = 10.1103/PhysRevLett.100.188102 | journal = Phys. Rev. Lett. | volume = 100 | issue = | page = 188102 | bibcode=2008PhRvL.100r8102C| arxiv = 1507.01344 }}available from arXiv:1507.01344, https://arxiv.org/abs/1507.01344</ref><ref name="giavazzi09">{{cite journal | last1 = Giavazzi | first1 = F. | last2 = Brogioli | first2 = D. | last3 = Trappe | first3 = V. | last4 = Bellini | first4 = T. | last5 = Cerbino | first5 = R. | year = 2009 | title = Scattering information obtained by optical microscopy: Differential Dynamic Microscopy and beyond | doi = 10.1103/PhysRevE.80.031403 | journal = Phys. Rev. E | volume = 80 | issue = | page = 031403 | bibcode = 2009PhRvE..80c1403G | url = http://doc.rero.ch/record/12910/files/trappe_sio.pdf }}</ref> DDM is suitable for typical [[Soft matter|soft materials]] such as for instance [[liquid]]s or [[gels]] made of [[colloids]], [[polymers]] and [[liquid crystal]]s but also for biological materials like bacteria and [[Cell (biology)|cells]].
==The basic idea== The typical DDM data is a time sequence of microscope images (movie) acquired at some height within the sample (typically at its mid-plane). If the image intensity is locally proportional to the concentration of particles or molecules to be studied (possibly convoluted with the microscope [[Point spread function|point spread function (PSF)]]), each movie can be analyzed in the Fourier space to obtain information about the dynamics of concentration Fourier modes, '''independent on the fact that the particles/molecules can be individually optically resolved or not'''. After suitable calibration also information about the Fourier amplitude of the concentration modes can be extracted.
==Applicability and working principle== The concentration-intensity proportionality is valid at least in two very important cases that distinguish two corresponding classes of DDM methods:
# '''scattering-based DDM''': where the image is the result of the superposition of the strong transmitted beam with the weakly scattered light from the particles. Typical cases where this condition can be obtained are [[Bright field microscopy|bright field]], [[phase contrast]], [[Polarized light microscopy|polarized]] microscopes. # '''fluorescence-based DDM''': where the image is the result of the incoherent addition of the intensity emitted by the particles ([[Fluorescent microscope|fluorescence]], [[Confocal microscopy|confocal]]) microscopes
In both cases the convolution with the [[Point spread function|PSF]] in the [[real coordinate space|real space]] corresponds to a simple product in the [[Reciprocal space|Fourier space]], which guarantees that studying a given Fourier mode of the image intensity provides information about the corresponding Fourier mode of the concentration field. In contrast with [[Single particle tracking|particle tracking]], there is no need of resolving the individual particles, which allows DDM to characterize the dynamics of particles or other moving entities whose size is much smaller than the wavelength of light. Still, the images are acquired in the real space, which provides several advantages with respect to traditional (far field) scattering methods.
==Data analysis== DDM is based on an algorithm proposed in<ref name="croccolo06">{{cite journal | last1 = Croccolo | first1 = F. | last2 = Brogioli | first2 = D. | last3 = Vailati | first3 = A. | last4 = Giglio | first4 = M. | last5 = Cannell | first5 = D. S. | year = 2006 | title = Use of dynamic schlieren interferometry to study fluctuations during free diffusion | url = | journal = Applied Optics | volume = 45 | issue = | page = 2166 | doi=10.1364/ao.45.002166| bibcode = 2006ApOpt..45.2166C }}</ref> and,<ref name="alaimo06">{{cite journal | last1 = Alaimo | first1 = M. | last2 = Magatti | first2 = D. | last3 = Ferri | first3 = F. | last4 = Potenza | first4 = M.A.C. | year = 2006 | title = Heterodyne speckle velocimetry | url = | journal = Appl. Phys. Lett. | volume = 88 | issue = | page = 191101 | doi=10.1063/1.2200396| bibcode = 2006ApPhL..88s1101A }}</ref> which is conveniently named [[Differential Dynamic Algorithm|Differential Dynamic Algorithm (DDA)]]. DDA works by subtracting images acquired at different times and taking advantage that, as the delay <math>\Delta t</math> between two subtracted images gets large, the energy content of the difference image increases correspondingly. A two-dimensional [[Fast Fourier transform|Fast Fourier Transform (FFT)]] analysis of the difference images allows to quantify the growth of the signal contains for each wave vector <math>q</math> and one can calculate the Fourier power spectrum of the difference images for different delays <math>\Delta t</math> to obtain the so-called ''image structure function'' <math>D(q;\Delta t)</math>. Calculation shows that for both scattering- and fluorescence-based DDM {{NumBlk|:|<math>D(q;\Delta t) =B(q)+T(q)I(q)[1-f(q;\Delta t)] \,</math>|{{EquationRef|1}}}} where <math>f(q;\Delta t)</math> is the normalized [[intermediate scattering function]] that would be measured in a [[Dynamic light scattering|Dynamic Light Scattering (DLS)]] experiment, <math>I(q)</math> the sample scattering intensity that would be measured in a [[Static light scattering|Static Light Scattering (SLS)]] experiment, <math>B(q)</math> a background term due to the noise along the detection chain <math>T(q)</math> a transfer function that depends on the microscope details.<ref name="giavazzi09" /> Equation ({{EquationNote|1}}) shows that DDM can be used for [[Dynamic light scattering|DLS]] experiments, provided that a model for the normalized [[intermediate scattering function]] is available.<ref name="giavazzi09" /> For instance, in the case of [[Brownian motion]] one has <math>f(q;\Delta t)=e^{-Dq^{2}\Delta t},</math> where <math>D</math> is the [[Mass diffusivity|diffusion coefficient]] of the Brownian particles. If the transfer function <math>T(q)</math> is determined by calibrating the microscope with a suitable sample, DDM can be employed also for [[Static light scattering|SLS]] experiments. Alternative algorithms for data analysis are suggested in.<ref name="giavazzi09" />
==Relationship with other imaging-based scattering methods== Scattering-based DDM belongs to the so-called '''near-field (or deep Fresnel) scattering''' family,<ref name="cerbino09">{{cite journal | last1 = Cerbino | first1 = R. | last2 = Vailati | first2 = A. | year = 2009 | title = Near-field scattering techniques: Novel instrumentation and results from time and spatially resolved investigations of soft matter systems", Curr. Op. Coll. Int | doi = 10.1016/j.cocis.2009.07.003 | journal = Science | volume = 14 | issue = | pages = 416–425 }}</ref> a recently introduced family of imaging-based scattering methods.<ref name="giglio00">{{cite journal | last1 = Giglio | first1 = M. | last2 = Carpineti | first2 = M. | last3 = Vailati | first3 = A. | year = 2000 | title = Space intensity correlations in the near field of the scattered light: a direct measurement of the density correlation function g(r) | doi = 10.1103/PhysRevLett.85.1416 | journal = Phys. Rev. Lett. | volume = 85 | issue = | pages = 1416–1419 | bibcode=2000PhRvL..85.1416G | pmid=10970518}}</ref><ref name="brogioli02">{{cite journal | last1 = Brogioli | first1 = D. | last2 = Vailati | first2 = A. | last3 = Giglio | first3 = M. | year = 2002 | title = Heterodyne near-field scattering | doi = 10.1063/1.1524702 | journal = Appl. Phys. Lett. | volume = 81 | issue = | page = 4109 | arxiv = physics/0305102 | bibcode = 2002ApPhL..81.4109B }}</ref> ''Near field'' is used here in a similar way to what is used for [[Speckle pattern#Near-field speckles|near field speckles]] i.e. as a particular case of Fresnel region as opposed to the ''far field'' or Fraunhofer region. The near field scattering family includes also quantitative [[shadowgraph]]y<ref name="wu95">{{cite journal | last1 = Wu | first1 = M. | last2 = Ahlers | first2 = G. | last3 = Cannell | first3 = D. S. | year = 1995 | title = Thermally induced fluctuations below the onset of Rayleigh-Bénard convection | doi = 10.1103/PhysRevLett.75.1743 | journal = Phys. Rev. Lett. | volume = 75 | issue = | pages = 1743–1746 | bibcode=1995PhRvL..75.1743W | pmid=10060380| arxiv = patt-sol/9502002 }}</ref> and [[Schlieren]].<ref name="croccolo06" />
==Applications of DDM== DDM was introduced in 2008 and it was applied for characterizing the dynamics of [[colloidal particle]]s in [[Brownian motion]].<ref name="cerbino08" /> More recently it has been successfully applied also to the study of aggregation processes of colloidal nanoparticles,<ref name="ferri11">{{cite journal | last1 = Ferri | first1 = F. | last2 = D'Angelo | first2 = A. | last3 = Lee | first3 = M. | last4 = Lotti | first4 = A. | last5 = Pigazzini | first5 = M.C. | last6 = Singh | first6 = K. | last7 = Cerbino | first7 = R. | year = 2011 | title = Kinetics of colloidal fractal aggregation by differential dynamic microscopy | doi = 10.1140/epjst/e2011-01509-9 | journal = Eur. Phys. J. | volume = 199 | issue = | pages = 139–148 | bibcode = 2011EPJST.199..139F }}</ref> of bacterial motions<ref name="wilson11">{{cite journal | last1 = Wilson | first1 = L. G. | last2 = Martinez | first2 = V. A. | last3 = Schwarz-Linek | first3 = J. | last4 = Tailleur | first4 = J. | last5 = Bryant | first5 = G. | last6 = Pusey | first6 = P. N. | last7 = Poon | first7 = W. C. K. | year = 2011 | title = Differential dynamic microscopy of bacterial motility | doi = 10.1103/PhysRevLett.106.018101 | journal = Phys. Rev. Lett. | volume = 106 | issue = | page = 018101 | bibcode=2011PhRvL.106a8101W| arxiv = 1004.4764 }}</ref><ref name="martinez12">V. A. Martinez, R. Besseling, O. A. Croze, J. Tailleur, M. Reufer, J. Schwarz-Linek, L. G. Wilson, M. A. Bees, W. C. K. Poon "Differential dynamic microscopy: A high-throughput method for characterizing the motility of microorganisms", available from arXiv:1202.1702v1, https://arxiv.org/abs/1202.1702v1</ref> and of the dynamics of anisotropic colloids.<ref name="reufer12">{{cite journal | last1 = Reufer | first1 = M. | last2 = Martinez | first2 = V. A. | last3 = Schurtenberger | first3 = P. | last4 = Poon | first4 = W. C. K. | year = | title = Differential Dynamic Microscopy for Anisotropic Colloidal Dynamics | doi = 10.1021/la204904a | journal = Langmuir | volume = 28| issue = | pages = 4618–4624}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [https://sites.google.com/site/cerbino/research/ddm DDM page on the personal website of Roberto Cerbino]
<!--- Categories ---> [[Category:Scientific techniques]] [[Category:Microscopy]] [[Category:Scattering, absorption and radiative transfer (optics)]] [[Category:Biochemistry methods]] [[Category:Physical chemistry]] [[Category:Spectroscopy]]

revision.comment: Dating maintenance tags: {{Cn}}
revision.text:
'''Display Energy Certificates''' (DECs) are records of the actual energy usage of public buildings, introduced by a number of European governments in response to the EU Energy Performance of Buildings Directive, which all EU member states had to implement by January 2009. DECs are designed to increase transparency about the energy efficiency of public buildings. The certificate looks similar to the energy labels provided on new cars and electrical appliances such as fridges and freezers – it uses a similar scale for energy efficiency, i.e. from A to G with A being the most efficient and G the least. The aim of the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive is for the public to receive energy information about a building they are visiting.
In [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]], the display of a DEC became mandatory for all public buildings over 1,000m² from 1 January, 2009. Since 9 July 2015, all public buildings in the [[United Kingdom|UK]] over 250m² must display a DEC prominently at all times. Where the building has a total useful floor area of more than 1,000m², a UK DEC is valid for 12 months. The accompanying advisory report is valid for seven years. Where the building has a total useful floor area of between 250m² and 999m², the DEC and advisory report are valid for 10 years.{{cn|date=July 2018}}
DECs are designed to promote the improvement of the energy performance of buildings. The A3 sized certificate is valid for one year and is accompanied by an Advisory Report (AR) which is valid for seven years. The advisory report is designed to help building owners and occupiers to improve the energy efficiency of their buildings so that future DECs show a better rating. ARs do not need to be displayed, but must be available.
DECs and ARs must be undertaken by an accredited energy assessors using approved software. In order to produce the DEC the energy assessor needs to know the gross internal floor area of the building and the operating hours together with actual meter readings or consignment notes for all fuels used during the year of assessment. It is, therefore, important for owners and occupiers of public buildings over 1,000m² to maintain good records of fuel used. If the energy assessor does not have access to suitable and sufficient information then a DEC cannot be produced.
==United Kingdom== The option to generate a default G rating was withdrawn in the UK on April 16, 2011.
The penalty for each breach is £500 for failing to display a DEC at all times in a prominent place clearly visible to the public and £1,000 for failing to have possession of a valid advisory report. In addition to these penalties, it is still necessary to commission a DEC and an advisory report.
In the future the Government is expected to extend the requirement for DECs large privately owned buildings which the public have access to, such as supermarkets.
[https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/452481/DEC_Guidance__rev_July_2015_.pdf DEC_Guildance]
== See also == {{Portal|Energy}} *[[Energy Performance Certificate]] *[[Energy use and conservation in the United Kingdom]] *[[Energy White Paper]]
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20071126061054/http://www.communities.gov.uk/planningandbuilding/theenvironment/energyperformance/certificates/displayenergycertificates/displayenergycertificates/ www.communities.gov.uk/faq] *[http://www.opsi.gov.uk/SI/si2007/20070991.htm The Energy Performance of Buildings (Certificates and Inspections) (England and Wales) Regulations 2007 No 991]<ref>1</ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20081110192330/http://www.communities.gov.uk/planningandbuilding/theenvironment/energyperformance/publiccommercialbuildings/displayenergycertificates/ Commercial buildings Display energy certificates]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Energy in the United Kingdom|govreg}}
[[Category:Energy in Europe]] [[Category:Law in the United Kingdom]]

revision.text:
[[File:RittnerErdpyramiden.jpg|thumb|The earth pyramids of Ritten]] [[File:Rittner Erdpyramiden 02 (HS).jpg|thumb|As seen from the west with Nicholas chapel and Dolomites]] [[File:Ritten (61).JPG|thumb|Pyramids in Autumn, as seen from Nicholas chapel]] The '''earth pyramids of Ritten''' (German: ''Erdpyramiden am Ritten''; {{lang-it|Piramidi di terra del Renon}} {{IPA-it|piˈraːmidi di ˈtɛrra del reˈnon|}}) are a natural monument that is located on the [[Ritten]], a [[plateau]] not far from [[Bolzano]] in northern Italy. The [[earth pyramids of South Tyrol]] are a fairly widespread phenomenon which are existing in various locations.
<!-- [[File:RittenLehmpyramiden.jpg|left|thumb|Another view of the Pyramids of the Ritten towards Mittelberg]] picture not upright, fj --> The original name in this area for these earth pyramids is ''Lahntürme'', i.e. landslide towers.<ref>Cfr. Paul Stacul, ''Die erste Erwähnung der Südtiroler Erdpyramiden'' (''The first mention of the South Tyrolean earth pyramides''), in "[[Der Schlern]]", 51, 1977, pp. 675-678.</ref> They are rather unusual formations of their kind which originate from morainic rocks of glacial origin. The columns of the pyramids may be more or less elongated, and the higher they are the thinner they get, ending usually with a stone cover. These earth pyramids are not static, they are constantly evolving, because their life cycle foresees a continuous [[erosion]], or even a final collapse leaving room for new formations.
In [[South Tyrol]] there are other natural monuments like this such as the [[earth pyramids of Platten]], but the ones of Ritten are considered the parents of them all.
==References== <references/>
==Further reading== * Fritz Dörrenhaus, Hans Becker: ''Der Ritten und seine Erdpyramiden. Vergleichende Betrachtung der Entstehung von Erdpyramiden in verschiedenen Klimagebieten der Erde'' (''The Ritten and its earth pyramides. Comparative examination of the formation of earth pyramides in distinct climate regions of the earth''), Kölner Geographische Arbeiten (Cologne Geographical Works), 17, Wiesbaden, Steiner, 1966.
== External links == {{Commons category}}
[[Category:Geography of South Tyrol]] [[Category:Erosion landforms]] [[Category:Natural monuments| ]]

revision.comment: /* See also */ {{Portal|Turkmenistan|Energy}}
revision.text:
{{Distinguish|West–East Gas Pipeline}} {{Infobox pipeline | name = East–West pipeline | type = [[natural gas]] | photo = | caption = | map = Казахстан и СредАзия газопроводы.png | map_caption = Location of East–West pipeline | country = [[Turkmenistan]] | state = | province = | coordinates = | lat = | long = | direction = east–west | start = Shatlyk compressor station | through = | finish = Belek-1 compressor station | par = | owner = | partners = | operator = [[Türkmengaz]] | technical_service_provider= | contractors = Türkmennebitgazgurlushyk | construction= 2010 | expected = 2015 | est = | decom = | length_km = 773 | discharge = {{convert|30|e9m3/a|abbr=off}} | diameter_mm = 1420 | compressor_stations_no= 8 | compressor_stations= }} The '''East–West pipeline''' is a [[natural gas]] [[Pipeline transport|pipeline]] in [[Turkmenistan]]. It will carry natural gas from gas fields in eastern Turkmenistan to the coast of [[Caspian Sea]] across the southern part of the country.
==History== In 2007–2008, Russia and Turkmenistan negotiated construction of the East–West pipeline to supply the planned [[Caspian Coastal pipeline]], an extension of the [[Central Asia–Center gas pipeline system]]. The pipeline was to be built in cooperation with the Russian gas company [[Gazprom]].<ref name=rbc240510/> The main designated contractor was Zarubezhneftegaz, a subsidiary of Gazprom.<ref name=edm210409> {{cite news | url= http://www.jamestown.org/single/?no_cache=1&tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=34884 | title= Turkmenistan Delays Russian Pipeline Project and Rejects Russian-Led Gas Cartel | publisher = [[The Jamestown Foundation]] | newspaper = [[Eurasia Daily Monitor]] | first = Vladimir | last = Socor | authorlink = Vladimir Socor | issue = 76 | volume = 6 | date=2009-04-21 | accessdate=2010-05-29}} </ref> However, on 27 March 2009 after tensions between Russia and Turkmenistan over gas supplies from Turkmenistan to Russia, Turkmenistan launched an international tender for the pipeline.<ref name=edm210409/><ref name=nca060409> {{cite news | url= http://www.newscentralasia.net/moreNews.php?nID=398 | title= East-West Gas Pipeline of Turkmenistan: An Open End Tube | agency = News Central Asia | date=2009-04-06 | accessdate=2010-05-29}} </ref> Over 70 companies expressed their interest to participate in the project. In May 2010 it was announced that Turkmenistan will build the pipeline on its own.<ref name=rbc240510> {{cite news | url= http://www.rbcnews.com/komment/komment.shtml?2010/05/24/32820654 | title= Turkmenistan's trump card | agency = RosBusinessConsulting | date=2010-05-24 | accessdate=2010-05-29}} </ref><ref name=eurasia240510> {{cite news | url= http://www.oilandgaseurasia.com/news/p/0/news/7399 | title= Turkmengaz to Finance East-West Pipeline Link to Caspian | publisher= Eurasia Press, Inc. | agency = Oil and Gas Information Agency | work = Oil & Gas Eurasia | date=2010-05-24 | accessdate=2010-05-29}} </ref> Construction started in 2012 and was completed in 2015.<ref name=trend110412> {{cite news | url= http://en.trend.az/capital/energy/2013403.html | title= Turkmenistan accelerates East-West gas pipeline construction | agency = [[Trend News Agency]] | date=2012-04-11 | accessdate=2012-04-11}} </ref><ref name=trend111215> {{cite news | url= http://en.trend.az/business/energy/2468538.html | title= Turkmenistan completing East-West gas pipeline construction | first = Huseyn | last = Hasanov | agency = [[Trend News Agency]] | date=2015-12-11 | accessdate=2015-12-11}} </ref>
==Route== The pipeline starts from the Shatlyk compressor station at the eastern branch of the Central Asia–Center gas pipeline in [[Mary Province]] and runs to the Belek-1 compressor station at the western branch of the Central Asia–Center gas pipeline in [[Balkan Province]].<ref name=zaman250510> {{cite news | url= http://www.todayszaman.com/tz-web/news-211069-105-turkmenistan-to-build-new-natural-gas-pipeline.html | title= Turkmenistan to build new natural gas pipeline | publisher=Feza Gazetecilik A.Ş. | newspaper=[[Today's Zaman]] | date=2010-05-25 | accessdate=2010-05-29}} </ref><ref name=nca210510/> From there, gas could be transported to Russia or, when constructed, through the [[Trans-Caspian Gas Pipeline]] to [[Azerbaijan]] and further to Europe.<ref name=eurasia240510/> In addition to export, the pipeline will supply the central and Caspian region of Turkmenistan.<ref name=zaman250510/> The pipeline largely follows the route of existing pipelines. It creates a system connecting all the major gas fields of Turkmenistan.<ref name=nca210510> {{cite news | url= http://www.newscentralasia.net/moreNews.php?nID=603 | title= Turkmenistan to Start Building East-West Gas Pipeline in June 2010 | agency = News Central Asia | date=2010-05-21 | accessdate=2010-05-29}} </ref>
==Description== The pipeline will be mainly supplied from the [[Galkynysh Gas Field]], [[Dauletabad gas field|Dauletabad]], Yashlar, and Minara fields. Length of the pipeline is {{convert|773|km}} and it will have a capacity of {{convert|30|e9m3|abbr=off}} of natural gas per year, ensured by eight compressor stations.<ref name=eurasia240510/><ref name=trend111215/><ref name=zaman250510/> The pipeline is being built by Türkmennebitgazgurlushyk and is owned and operated by [[Türkmengaz]].<ref name=zaman250510/><ref name=nca210510/>
==See also== {{Portal|Turkmenistan|Energy}} * [[Central Asia – China gas pipeline]] * [[Dauletabad–Sarakhs–Khangiran pipeline]] * [[Korpezhe–Kurt Kui pipeline]] * [[Nabucco pipeline]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:East-West pipeline}} [[Category:Natural gas pipelines in Turkmenistan]] [[Category:Energy in Central Asia]]

revision.text:
==Oil== Paraguay consumed {{convert|28000|oilbbl/d|abbr=on}} of [[petroleum]] in 2006. It does not currently produce any [[crude oil]]. In February 2006, Paraguay’s Public Works Ministry announced that oil had been discovered in the western [[Gran Chaco|Chaco region]] by British oil company [[CDS Energy Services|CDS]], though CDS stated that the reservoir was too tight to facilitate unassisted oil production.<ref name=ca>[http://www.eia.doe.gov/emeu/cabs/Paraguay_Uruguay/Background.html Country analysis brief: Paraguay/Uruguay]. [[Energy Information Administration]] (November 2006).</ref>
State-owned [[Petróleos Paraguayos]] (Petropar) has a monopoly on all crude oil and petroleum product sales and imports in Paraguay. It operates Paraguay's sole refinery, the {{convert|7500|oilbbl/d|abbr=on}} Villa Elisa facility.<ref name=ca/>
Like many oil-importing countries in the Western Hemisphere, Paraguay has tried to foster the development of special deals for importing crude oil and refined products from [[Venezuela]]. Paraguay, along with [[Uruguay]], signed a deal in 2005 to receive crude oil imports from Venezuela under preferential financing terms. In December 2005, [[ANCAP (Uruguay)|ANCAP]] and [[PdVSA]], the Uruguayan and Venezuelan national oil companies, agreed to fund a study for the proposed doubling of the capacity at the La Teja plant. The project, which would cost an estimated $800 million, would also upgrade facilities at the refinery so that it could handle heavier Venezuelan crude varieties.<ref name=ca/>
==Natural gas== Paraguay has no proven [[natural gas reserves]], and it neither produces nor consumes natural gas. In recent years, the country has sought to promote the consumption of natural gas as a way to decrease the use of firewood and charcoal, which has contributed to deforestation in the country. However, barriers to natural gas consumption include a lack of domestic natural gas production and the absence of import pipelines.<ref name=ca/>
Paraguay has attracted some interest from international natural gas companies, with UK-based CDS Oil & Gas announcing in early 2004 that it had successfully completed a production test at its Independencia-1 well in the northwestern part of the country. Other companies that have signed exploration concessions with Paraguay’s government include [[H.A & E.R. Exploraciones]], [[Pilcomayo Petróleos]] S.A., [[Hidroener Consultora]], [[Guaraní Exploration]], [[Union Oil]], [[Paraguay Gas]], [[Boreal Petróleos]], [[Aurora Petróleos]] and [[Amerisur]].<ref name=ca/>
Paraguay has pursued several natural gas import options. In 2001, Brazil proposed the [[Gas Integration Project]] (Gasin), a natural gas pipeline linking Bolivia, Argentina, Paraguay, and Brazil. There has not been much progress to date on the implementation of this proposal. In 2002, the Bolivian and Paraguayan governments signed a preliminary agreement allowing for the construction of a pipeline from southern Bolivia to Asuncion. In June 2006, the two governments approved a plan to move forward with the pipeline, which would have an initial capacity of {{convert|700|e6cuft/d|m3/d}} and require an investment of at least $2 billion.<ref name=ca/>
==Electricity== Paraguay [[electricity generation|generated]] 51.8 [[terawatt]]-hours of electricity in 2004, while consuming only 3.1 TWh. Almost all of the country’s electricity consumption comes from a single facility, the bi-national [[Itaipu dam]]. Paraguay is one of the world’s largest net exporters of electric power.<ref name=ca/>
Paraguay's state-owned utility, [[Administracion Nacional de Electricidad]] (ANDE), controls the country’s entire electricity market, including generation, distribution and transmission. It operates a single [[hydroelectric]] dam, [[Acaray Dam|Acaray]], and six [[thermal power plant]]s, with total installed capacity of 220 megawatts (MW). The company is also responsible for Paraguay’s share of two bi-national hydroelectric facilities (see below). ANDE operates {{convert|2100|mi|km|order=flip}} of transmission lines and {{convert|670|mi|km|order=flip|abbr=on}} of distribution lines. Over 92 percent of the country has electricity service.<ref name=ca/>
Paraguay operates two hydroelectric dams in cooperation with its neighbors: [[Itaipu Dam|Itaipu]] (Brazil) and [[Yacyretá Dam|Yacyreta]] (Argentina). The Itaipu dam was the largest hydroelectric facility in the world, before the completion of the [[Three Gorges Dam]] in China. Itaipu has 18 generators and a total installed capacity of 14,000 MW, evenly shared between Paraguay and Brazil. In 2004, Paraguay consumed 16 percent of its share of Itaipu production, exporting the rest to Brazil. Yacyreta, completed in 1999, has 20 generators and a total installed capacity of 3,100 MW. In 2014 Paraguay consumed almost 5 percent of its share of Yacyreta’s production, exporting the rest to Argentina.<ref>[http://www.hoy.com.py/nacionales/revelan-cifra-que-usara-argentina-para-revision-de-tratado-de-yacyreta Revelan cifra que usará Argentina para revisión del tratado de Yacyretá]</ref> In September 2006, Ente Binacional Yacyreta, the binational company responsible for operating the facility, announced that it was cancelling the planned Aña Cuá expansion of the facility.<ref name=ca/>
==See also== *[[Mineral industry of Paraguay]]
==References== {{reflist}} {{South America topic|Energy in}} {{Paraguay topics}}
[[Category:Energy in Paraguay| ]]

revision.text:
{{Globalize/UK|date=May 2008}}
A '''flood risk assessment''' (FRA) is an [[Risk assessment|assessment of the risk]] of [[flood]]ing from all flooding mechanisms, the identification of flood mitigation measures and should provide advice on actions to be taken before and during a flood.
The sources of water which produce floods include: * [[Groundwater]] (saturated groundwater) * [[Vadose zone|Vadose]] (water flowing the ground in an unsaturated state) * Surface water * Artificial water (burst water mains, canals or reservoirs) * Rivers, streams or watercourses * Sewers and drains *Flooding of low-lying coastal regions due to [[sea level rise]]
For each of the sources of water, different hydraulic intensities occur. Floods can occur because of a combination of sources of flooding, such as high groundwater and an inadequate surface water drainage system. The topography, hydrogeology and physical attributes of the existing or proposed development need to be considered. A flood risk assessment should be an evaluation of the flood risk and the consequences and impact and [http://planningguidance.planningportal.gov.uk/blog/guidance/flood-risk-and-coastal-change/flood-zone-and-flood-risk-tables/table-2-flood-risk-vulnerability-classification/ vulnerability].
''Non-professiona''l flood risk assessments can be produced by members of the public, Architects, environment assessors, or others who are not specifically professionally qualified in this field. However, it is a complex evaluation and such assessments they can be rejected by Authorities as inadequate, or could be considered as negligent in the event of a flooding event, damage and a claim to insurers being made.
'''In the UK, the writing of''' '''''professional''''' '''flood risk assessments''' '''is undertaken by Civil Engineering Consultants'''. They will have membership of the [[Institution of Civil Engineers]] and are bound by their [https://www.ice.org.uk/ICEDevelopmentWebPortal/media/Documents/About%20Us/ice-code-of-professional-conduct.pdf rules of professional conduct]. A key requirement is to ensure such professional flood risk assessments are independent to all parties by carrying out their professional duties with complete objectivity and impartiality. Their professional advice should be supported by [[professional indemnity insurance]] for such specific professional advice ultimately held with a [[Lloyd's of London]] underwriter.
Professional flood risk assessments can cover single buildings, or whole regions. They can part of a due-diligence process for existing householders or businesses, or can be required in England and Wales to provide independent evidence to a planning application on the flood risk.
==England and Wales== In England and Wales, the [[Environment Agency]] requires a professional Flood Risk Assessment (FRA) to be submitted alongside planning applications in areas that are known to be at risk of flooding (within flood zones 2 or 3) and/ or are greater than 1ha in area, [[planning permission]] is not usually granted until the FRA has been accepted by the Environment Agency.
===PPS 25 – England only=== Flood Risk Assessments are required to be completed according to the National Planning Policy Framework,<ref>National Planning Policy Framework (https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/6077/2116950.pdf) "National Planning Policy Framework"</ref> which replaces [[Planning Policy Statement]] PPS 25: Development and Flood Risk. The initial legislation (PPG25) was introduced in 2001 and subsequently revised.<ref>HMSO (2006, Revised 2010) [http://www.communities.gov.uk/documents/planningandbuilding/pdf/planningpolicystatement25.pdf ''Planning Policy Statement 25: Development and Flood Risk''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100215083945/http://www.communities.gov.uk/documents/planningandbuilding/pdf/planningpolicystatement25.pdf |date=2010-02-15 }}, TSO, London. {{ISBN|978-0-11-754099-6}}</ref>
[[PPS 25]] was designed to "strengthen and clarify the key role of the planning system in managing flood risk and contributing to adapting to the impacts of climate change."<ref>Angela Smith MP (7 December 2006) [http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20100408000121/http://www.communities.gov.uk/statements/corporate/planning-policy-flooding Planning Policy Statement (PPS) 25: Flooding], Written Parliamentary Statement</ref> and sets out policies for local authorities to ensure flood risk is taken into account during the planning process to prevent inappropriate development in high risk areas and to direct development away from areas at highest risk.
In its introduction, PPS25 states "flooding threatens life and causes substantial damage to property [and that] although [it] cannot be wholly prevented, its impacts can be avoided and reduced through good planning and management".<ref>Communities and Local Government (2006) [http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20080306200436/http://www.communities.gov.uk/documents/planningandbuilding/pdf/153740 ''Planning Policy Statement 25: Development and Flood Risk: Full Regulatory Impact Assessment'']</ref>
===Composition of an FRA=== For a flood risk assessment to be written, information is needed concerning the existing and proposed developments, the Environment Agency modeled flood levels and topographic levels on site. At its most simple (and cheapest) level an FRA can provide an indication of whether a development will be allowed to take place at a site.
An initial idea of the risk of fluvial flooding to a local area can be found on the [http://www.environment-agency.gov.uk/subjects/flood/ Environment Agency flood map website].
FRAs consist of a detailed analysis of available data to inform the Environment Agency of flood risk at an individual site and also recommend to the developer any mitigation measures. More costly analysis of flood risk can be achieved through detailed flood modelling to challenge the agency's modelled levels and corresponding flood zones.
The FRA takes into account the risk and impact of flooding on the site, and takes into consideration how the development may affect flooding in the local area. It also includes provides recommendations as to how the risk of flooding to the development can be mitigated.
FRAs should also consider flooding from all sources including fluvial, groundwater, surface water runoff and sewer flooding.
==Northern Ireland== In 2006, the [[Planning Service]], part of [[Department of the Environment (Northern Ireland)|The Department of the Environment]], published Planning Policy Statement 15 (PPS15): Planning and flood risk.<ref>Department of the Environment (2006) [http://www.planningni.gov.uk/index/policy/policy_publications/planning_statements/pps15-flood-risk.pdf Planning Policy Statement 15 (PPS 15): Planning and Flood Risk], The Planning Service, Belfast</ref> The guidelines are precautionary and advise against development in flood plains and areas subject to historical flooding. In exceptional cases a FRA can be completed to justify development in flood risk areas. Advice on flood risk assessment is provided to the Planning Service by the [[Rivers Agency]], which is the statutory drainage and flood defence authority for [[Northern Ireland]].
==Republic of Ireland== In 2009, the [[Department of the Environment, Community and Local Government|Department of the Environment, Heritage and Local Government]] and [[Office of Public Works]] published planning guidelines requiring local authorities to apply a sequential approach to flood risk management.<ref>Government of Ireland (2009) [http://www.environ.ie/en/Publications/DevelopmentandHousing/Planning/FileDownLoad,21708,en.pdf The Planning System and Flood Risk Management], The Stationery Office, Dublin {{ISBN|978-1-4064-2467-6}}</ref> The guidelines require that proposed development in flood risk areas must undergo a justification test, consisting of a flood risk assessment.
==See also== *[[Flood warning]]
* [[Floods directive]] * [[Flood Modeller Pro|Flood Modeller (software used to undertake flood risk assessments)]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links==
{{DEFAULTSORT:Flood Risk Assessment}} [[Category:Natural hazards]] [[Category:Flood control]] [[Category:Environmental policy in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Extreme value data]]

revision.comment: clean up; move SA; edit links; compact; using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{orphan|date=November 2012}} {{more footnotes|date=November 2012}} {{lead too short|date=November 2012}} {{underlinked|date=November 2012}} }}
The '''hybrid difference scheme'''<ref>{{cite book|last=Patankar|first=Suhas V.|title=Numerical heat transfer and fluid flow|year=1980|publisher=Taylor & Francis|location=Bristol, PA|isbn=9780891165224|edition=14. printing.}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Versteeg|first=H.K.|title=An introduction to computational fluid dynamics : the finite volume method|year=2007|publisher=Prentice Hall|location=Harlow|isbn=9780131274983|edition=2nd |author2=Malalasekera, W.}}</ref> is a method used in the numerical solution for [[Convection–diffusion equation|convection–diffusion]] problems. It was first introduced by [[Brian Spalding|Spalding]] (1970). It is a combination of [[Central differencing scheme|central difference scheme]] and [[Upwind scheme|upwind difference scheme]] as it exploits the favorable properties of both of these schemes.<ref name=Scarborough>Scarborough, J.B.(1958) Numerical Mathematical Analysis, 4th edn, Johns Hopkins University Press, Baltimore, MD.</ref><ref name=Spalding>Spalding, D.B. (1972). A Novel Finite-difference Formulation for Differential Expression Involving Both First and Second Derivatives, Int. J. Numer. Methods Eng., Vol. 4.</ref>
==Introduction<ref name=Pollard>Pollard, A. and Siu, A. L. W. (1982). The Calculation of Some Laminar Flows Using Various Discretization Schemes, Comput. Methods Appl. Mech. Eng., Vol. 35.</ref>== Hybrid difference scheme is a method used in the numerical solution for convection-diffusion problems. These problems play important roles in [[computational fluid dynamics]]. It can be described by the general partial equation as follows:<ref name=Borris>Borris, J.P. and Brook, D.L. (1976). Solution of the Continuity Equation by the Method of Flux Corrected Transport, J. Comput. Phys., Vol. 16.</ref>
:<math>\frac{\partial}{\partial t}(\rho\phi)+\nabla (\rho \mathbf{u} \phi)\,= \nabla (\Gamma \cdot \operatorname{grad} \phi)+S_{\phi} </math><math>\;</math> ({{EquationRef|1}})
Where, <math>\rho</math> is [[density]], <math>\mathbf{u}</math> is the velocity vector, <math>\Gamma</math> is the [[Mass diffusivity|diffusion coefficient]] and <math>S_{\phi}</math> is the source term. In this equation property, <math>\phi</math> can be [[temperature]], [[internal energy]] or component of velocity vector <math>\mathbf{u}</math> in x, y and z directions.
For one-dimensional analysis of convection-diffusion problem in steady state and without the source the equation reduces to,
:<math>\frac{\partial}{\partial x}(\rho u \phi)\,= \frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left(\Gamma\frac{\partial \phi}{\partial x}\right),\quad 0<x<L\; </math> <math>\;</math> ({{EquationRef|2}})
With boundary conditions, <math>\phi (0)\,= \phi_0</math> and <math>\phi (L)\, = \phi_{L}</math>, where L is the length, <math>\phi_0</math> and <math>\phi_{L}</math> are the given values.
==Grid generation== Integrating equation {{EquationRef|2}} over the [[control volume]] containing node N, and using [[Divergence theorem|Gauss’ theorem]] i.e.,
:<math>\int_{CV} \nabla (\rho\mathbf{u}\phi)dV \,= \int_{A} \mathbf{n} \cdot (\rho\mathbf{u}\phi)dA</math> <math>\;</math> ({{EquationRef|3}})
Yields the following result,
:<math>\left(\rho u A \phi \right)_{r} - \left(\rho u A \phi \right)_{l}</math> = <math>\left(\Gamma A \frac{\partial \phi}{\partial x}\right)_{r} - \left(\Gamma A \frac{\partial \phi}{\partial x}\right)_{l}</math> <math>\;</math>({{EquationRef|4}})
Where, A is the [[Cross section (geometry)|cross-sectional]] area of the control volume. The equation must also satisfy the [[continuity equation]], i.e.,
:<math>\left(\rho u A \right)_{r} - \left(\rho u A \right)_{l}</math> = 0 <math>\;</math> ({{EquationRef|5}})
Now let us define variables F and D to represent the '''convection mass flux''' and '''diffusion conductance''' at cell faces,
:<math>F\,= \rho u A</math><math>\;</math> and <math>\;</math><math>D\,= \frac{\Gamma A}{\delta x}</math> <math>\;</math> ({{EquationRef|6}})
Hence, equations ({{EquationRef|4}}) and ({{EquationRef|5}}) transform into the following equations:
:<math> F_{r} \phi_{r}-F_{l} \phi_{l}\,= D_{r}(\phi_{R}-\phi_{N})-D_{l}(\phi_{N}-\phi_{L})</math> <math>\;</math> ({{EquationRef|7}})
:<math> F_{r}-F_{l}\,=0</math> <math>\;</math> ({{EquationRef|8}})
Where, the lower case letters denote the values at the faces and the upper case letters denote that at the nodes. We also define a non-dimensional parameter [[Péclet number]] (Pe) as a measure of the relative strengths of convection and diffusion,
:<math> Pe \,= \frac{F}{D} \,= \frac{\rho u}{\Gamma / \delta x}</math> <math>\;</math> ({{EquationRef|9}})
For a low Peclet number (|Pe|<2) the flow is characterized as dominated by diffusion. For large Peclet number the flow is dominated by convection.
==Central and upwind difference scheme<ref name="Scarborough"/><ref name=Roache>Roache, P.J.(1976) Computational Fluid Dynamics, Hermosa, Albuquerque, NM.</ref>==
[[File:The grid used for discretisation in Central Difference Scheme..png|thumb|400 px|Fig 1: The grid used for discretisation in Central Difference Scheme]] In the above equations ({{EquationRef|7}}) and ({{EquationRef|8}}), we observe that the values require are at the faces, instead of the nodes. Hence approximations are required to fulfill this.
In the central difference scheme we replace the value at the face with the average of the values at the adjacent nodes, :<math>\phi_{r}\,= \frac{\phi_{R} + \phi_{N}}{2}</math> <math>\;</math> and <math>\;</math> <math>\phi_{l}\,= \frac{\phi_{N} + \phi_{L}}{2}</math> <math>\;</math> ({{EquationRef|10}}) [[File:The grid used for discretisation in Upwind Difference Scheme for positive Peclet number (Pe 0)..png|thumb|300 px|Fig 2: The grid used for discretisation in Upwind Difference Scheme for positive Peclet number (Pe>0)]] [[File:The grid used for discretisation in Upwind Difference Scheme for negative Peclet number (Pe 0)..png|thumb|300 px|Fig 3: The grid used for discretisation in Upwind Difference Scheme for negative Peclet number (Pe < 0)]]
By putting these values in equation ({{EquationRef|7}}) and rearranging we get the following result,
:<math> a_{N} \phi_{N} \,= a_{R} \phi_{R} + a_{L} \phi_{L}</math> <math>\;</math> ({{EquationRef|11}})
where,
:{| class="wikitable" |- ! scope="col" style="width:200px;"| <math> a_{L} </math> ! scope="col" style="width:200px;"| <math> a_{R} </math> ! scope="col" style="width:200px;"| <math> a_{N} </math> |- | :<math> D_{l} + \frac{F_{l}}{2} </math>
| :<math>D_{r} - \frac{F_{r}}{2} </math> | :<math> a_{R} + a_{L} + (F_{r} - F_{l})</math> |}
In the Upwind scheme we replace the value at the face with the value at the adjacent upstream node. For example, for the flow to the right (Pe>0)as shown in the diagram, we replace the values as follows;
:<math> \phi_{l}\,= \phi_{L} </math><math>\;</math> and <math>\;</math><math> \phi_{r}\,= \phi_{N} </math> <math>\;</math> ({{EquationRef|12}})
And for Pe < 0, we put the values as shown in the figure 3,
:<math> \phi_{r}\,= \phi_{R} </math><math>\;</math> and <math>\;</math><math> \phi_{l}\,= \phi_{N} </math> <math>\;</math> ({{EquationRef|13}})
By putting these values in equation ({{EquationRef|7}}) and rearranging we get the same equation as equation ({{EquationRef|11}}), with the following values of the coefficients:
:{| class="wikitable" |- ! scope="col" style="width:200px;"| <math> a_{L} </math> ! scope="col" style="width:200px;"| <math> a_{R} </math> ! scope="col" style="width:200px;"| <math> a_{N} </math> |- | :<math> D_{l} + \max( F_{l} , 0) </math>
| :<math>D_{r} + \max( - F_{r} , 0)</math> | :<math> a_{R} + a_{L} + (F_{r} - F_{l})</math> |}
==Hybrid difference scheme<ref name="Scarborough"/><ref name="Roache"/>== [[File:Diagram showing the variation of any property (Ø) along the length (L) at different Peclet numbers (Pe)..png|thumb|300 px|Fig 4: Diagram showing the variation of any property (ϕ) along the length (L) at different Peclet numbers (Pe)]] The hybrid difference scheme of Spalding (1970) is a combination of the central difference scheme and upwind difference scheme. It makes use of the central difference scheme, which is second order accurate, for small Peclet numbers (|Pe| < 2). For large Peclet numbers (|Pe| > 2) it uses the Upwind difference scheme, which first order accurate but takes into account the convection of the fluid.
As it can be seen in figure 4 that for Pe = 0, it is a linear distribution and for high Pe it takes the upstream value depending on the flow direction. For example, the value at the left face, in different circumstances is,
: <math> \phi_{l}\,= \left [\left (1 + \frac{2}{ Pe_{l} }\right) \frac{\phi_{L}}{2} + \left (1 - \frac{2}{ Pe_{l} }\right) \frac{\phi_{N}}{2}\right ] \,</math> <math>\;</math> for <math>\;</math> <math> -2< Pe_{l} <2</math><math>\;</math> ({{EquationRef|14}})
: <math> \phi_{l}\,= \phi_{L}</math> <math>\;</math> for <math>\;</math> <math> Pe_{l} \text{≥} 2</math> <math>\;</math> ({{EquationRef|15}})
: <math> \phi_{l}\,= \phi_{N}</math> <math>\;</math> for <math>\;</math> <math> Pe_{l} \text{≤} -2</math> <math>\;</math> ({{EquationRef|16}})
Substituting these values in equation ({{EquationRef|7}}) we get the same equation ({{EquationRef|11}}) with the values of the coefficients as follows,
:{| class="wikitable" |- ! scope="col" style="width:200px;"| <math> a_{L} </math> ! scope="col" style="width:200px;"| <math> a_{R} </math> ! scope="col" style="width:200px;"| <math> a_{N} </math> |- | :<math> \max \left [ F_{l} , \left ( D_{l} + \frac{ F_{l}}{2} \right ), 0 \right ] </math>
| :<math> \max \left [ -F_{r} , \left ( D_{r} - \frac{ F_{r}}{2} \right ), 0 \right ] </math> | :<math> a_{r} + a_{l} + (F_{r} - F_{l})</math> |}
==Advantages and disadvantages== It exploits the favourable properties of the central difference and upwind scheme. It switches to upwind difference scheme when central difference scheme produces inaccurate results for high Peclet numbers. It produces physically realistic solution and has proved to be helpful in the prediction of practical flows. The only disadvantage associated with hybrid difference scheme is that the accuracy in terms of [[Taylor series]] [[truncation error]] is only first order.
==See also== * [[Upwind differencing scheme for convection]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * http://proceedings.fyper.com/eccomascfd2006/documents/595.pdf * http://www.internonlinearscience.org/upload/papers/20110228093510102.pdf * http://www.internonlinearscience.org/upload/papers/20110227034844410.pdf
[[Category:Transport phenomena]] [[Category:Diffusion]]

revision.comment: Adding Ramsar designation
revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=December 2009}} {{Infobox lake | name = Lake Uluabat | image = | caption = | image_bathymetry = | caption_bathymetry = | location = | coords = {{Coord|40|10|N|28|35|E|type:waterbody_region:TR|display=inline,title}} | type = | inflow = [[Mustafakemalpaşa River]] | outflow = Ulubat stream | catchment = | basin_countries = Turkey | embedded = {{Designation list | embed = yes | designation1 = Ramsar | designation1_date = 12 June 1998 | designation1_number = 944<ref>{{Cite web|title=Lake Uluabat|website=[[Ramsar Convention|Ramsar]] Sites Information Service|url=https://rsis.ramsar.org/ris/944|accessdate=25 April 2018}}</ref>}} | length = | width = | area = {{convert|135|to|160|km2|abbr=on}} | depth = | max-depth = {{convert|10|m|abbr=on}} | volume = | residence_time = | shore = | elevation = | islands = 8 (Halilbey Island) | cities = [[Gölyazı]] }} '''Lake Uluabat''' ({{lang-tr|'''Uluabat Gölü'''}} and '''''Apolyont Gölü''''') is the name of a freshwater lake in the vicinity of [[Bursa, Turkey]]. It is a large lake, covering an area of between 135 and 160 km<sup>2</sup> depending on the water level, but very shallow, being only 3 m deep at its deepest point. The lake contains eight islands and one other that is sometimes an island and sometimes a peninsula. The largest island is known as Halilbey Island. In the southwest the lake is fed by the [[Mustafakemalpaşa River]], which has formed a silty delta. Water leaves the lake by way of the Ulubat stream,{{citation needed|date=September 2011}} flowing to the west, and reaches the [[Sea of Marmara]] via the [[Susurluk River]].
Most shores of the lake are covered in submerged plants, and it has the most extensive [[white water lily]] beds in [[Turkey]]. Ulubat Lake is one of the breeding areas for the endangered [[pygmy cormorant]] (''Phalacrocorax pygmeus''). The latest DHKD (Society for the Protection of Nature Turkey) survey in June 1998 found 823 pygmy cormorant pairs, 105 [[night heron]] pairs, 109 [[squacco heron]] pairs, and 48 [[spoonbill]] pairs breeding on Ulubat.
The alternative name Lake ''Apolyont'' comes from the lake's [[greek language|greek]] classical name '''Apolloniatis''' (''Απολλωνιάτις''), from [[Apollonia ad Rhyndacum|Apollonia-on-the-Rhyndacum]] (modern [[Gölyazı]]), an ancient Greek city situated on its banks which had considerable importance since it was on major trade routes.
Modern residential areas by its shores are [[Mustafakemalpaşa]] (formerly [[Kirmasti]]) and [[Karacabey]] (formerly [[Mikalick]]). The area was famous for centuries for its [[silkworm cultivation]], but this industry has died out due to synthetic fabrics. The main industry today is fishing.
==Saint Constantine== St. Constantine is a small island inside the lake. During the Byzantine era, there was a monastery of St. Constantine on the island. Today the island is uninhabited, but the monastery has survived Ottoman conquest of [[Asia Minor]]. The [[Eastern Orthodox Church|orthodox]] monastery has received attention from scholars because of its inscribed cross type with apses east and west.<ref>Mango, Cyril. "The Monastery of St. Constantine on Lake Apolyont." ''Dumbarton Oaks Papers'', Vol. 33 (1979), pp. 329-333.</ref>
==Important Bird Area== The lake, which is in unprotected status, was declared by [[BirdLife International]] as an [[Important Bird Area]] in 1989 for its [[waterfowl]] species of international character and species, which are globally threatened.<ref name="kv">{{cite web |url=http://www.kasparek-verlag.de/MaxKasparek/PDF/1989%20GrimmetKasparekKilic.pdf |publisher= |title=Important Bird Areas In Turkey: Unprotected And Under Threat æauthors=Grimmett, R. F. A. & M. Kasparek, A. Kılıç, A. Ertan I|accessdate=2014-07-13 }}</ref>
==See also== * [[Ulubatlı Hasan]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Lakes of Turkey}} {{Ramsar sites in Turkey}}
[[Category:Lakes of Turkey|Uluabat]] [[Category:Ramsar sites in Turkey]] [[Category:Landforms of Bursa Province]] [[Category:Important Bird Areas of Turkey]]

page.title: List of National Monuments of the United States

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10) ([[User:FA RotBot|FA RotBot]])
revision.text:
There are 130 [[protected area]]s in the United States known as national monuments. The [[President of the United States]] can establish a [[National Monument (United States)|national monument]] by [[Presidential proclamation (United States)|presidential proclamation]], and the [[United States Congress]] can do so by legislation. The president's authority arises from the ''[[Antiquities Act]] of 1906'', which authorizes the president to proclaim "historic landmarks, historic and prehistoric structures, and other objects of historic or scientific interest" as national monuments.{{UnitedStatesCode|16|431}} {{UnitedStatesCodeSec|16|432}}, and {{UnitedStatesCodeSec|16|433}}. ''U.S. Code collection''. Cornell University Law School. Retrieved on 11 February 2009. Concerns about protecting mostly prehistoric [[Native Americans in the United States|Indian]] ruins and artifacts—collectively termed [[antiquities]]—on western federal lands prompted the legislation. Its purpose was to allow the president to quickly preserve public land without waiting for legislation to pass through an unconcerned Congress. The ultimate goal was to protect all historic and prehistoric sites on U.S. federal lands.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/history/history/hisnps/npshistory/righter.htm |title=National Monuments to National Parks:|last=Righter|first=Robert W.|date=March 5, 2005|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-02-05}} President [[Theodore Roosevelt]] established the first national monument, [[Devils Tower]] in [[Wyoming]], on September 24, 1906. He established 18 national monuments, although only nine still retain that designation.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/history/history/hisnps/NPSHistory/monuments.htm|title=National Monument Proclamations under the Antiquities Act|date=January 16, 2003|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-02-08}} Sixteen presidents have created national monuments since the program began; only [[Richard Nixon]], [[Ronald Reagan]], and [[George H. W. Bush]] did not.{{cite web|last=Janiskee|first=Bob|title=By the Numbers: National Monument|url=http://www.nationalparkstraveler.com/2010/08/numbers-national-monuments6283|work=National Parks Traveler|accessdate=29 October 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140307075423/http://www.nationalparkstraveler.com/2010/08/numbers-national-monuments6283|archive-date=2014-03-07|dead-url=yes|df=}} [[Bill Clinton]] created nineteen and expanded three others. [[Jimmy Carter]] protected vast parts of [[Alaska]], proclaiming fifteen national monuments, some of which later were promoted to [[national park]]s. President [[Barack Obama]] created or expanded 34 national monuments, the most of any president, with over half a billion acres of public land and water protected.{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2016/06/26/obamas-national-monuments-more-than-conservation/82931356/|title=Obama’s national monuments are about more than conservation|publisher=}}{{cite web|last=Eilperin|first=Juliet|title=In massive expansion of lands legacy, Obama creates three new national monuments|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/energy-environment/wp/2015/07/10/in-massive-expansion-of-lands-legacy-obama-creates-three-new-national-monuments/|publisher=Washington Post|accessdate=10 July 2015}} National monuments are located in 32 states as well as in the [[District of Columbia]], the [[United States Virgin Islands|Virgin Islands]], [[American Samoa]], the [[United States Minor Outlying Islands|Minor Outlying Islands]], and the [[Northern Mariana Islands]]. [[Arizona]], with 18, has the largest number of national monuments, followed by [[California]] with 17 and [[New Mexico]] with 14. At least 65 national monuments protect places of natural significance, including 12 geological sites, seven marine sites, and five volcanic sites. Twenty-three national monuments have major sites associated with Native Americans, while 34 are other historical sites, including twelve forts. Many [[:Category:Former National Monuments of the United States|former national monuments]] have been redesignated as national parks or another status by Congress, while others have been transferred to state control or disbanded. ==Analysis of management by federal agency and department== {{GeoGroupTemplate}} Eight [[List of United States federal agencies|federal agencies]] in five [[United States federal executive departments|departments]] manage the 130 current U.S. national monuments. Of these, 116 monuments are managed by a single agency, while 14 are co-managed by two agencies. One of the NPS's national monuments, [[Grand Canyon-Parashant National Monument|Grand Canyon-Parashant]], is not an [[List of the United States National Park System official units|official unit]] because it overlaps with [[Lake Mead National Recreation Area]]. {|class="wikitable sortable" |- !Agency !Department !Co-managed !Total managed |- |{{NMON color}}|[[National Park Service]] (NPS) |[[United States Department of the Interior|Interior]] | 2 with BLM, 1 with FWS | 89 |- |{{NMON color}}|[[Bureau of Land Management]] (BLM) |[[United States Department of the Interior|Interior]] | 2 with NPS, 5 with USFS | 27 |- |{{NMON color}}|[[United States Forest Service]] (USFS) |[[United States Department of Agriculture|Agriculture]] | 5 with BLM | 12 |- |{{NMON color}}|[[United States Fish and Wildlife Service|Fish and Wildlife Service]] (FWS) |[[United States Department of the Interior|Interior]] | 5 with NOAA, 1 with NPS, 1 with DOE | 8 |- |{{NMON color}}|[[United States Department of Energy|Department of Energy]] (DOE) |[[United States Department of Energy|Energy]] |1 with FWS |1 |- |{{NMON color}}|[[Armed Forces Retirement Home]] (AFRH) |[[United States Department of Defense|Defense]] | 1 with [[President Lincoln's Cottage at the Soldiers' Home]] | 1 |- |{{NMON color}}|[[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]] (NOAA) |[[United States Department of Commerce|Commerce]] | 5 with FWS |5 |- |{{NMON color}}|[[United States Air Force]] (USAF) |[[United States Department of Defense|Defense]] | | 1 |- | (duplications) | | | (14) |- class=sortbottom | colspan=3|'''Total''' | '''130''' |} ==List of national monuments== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="width:98%" |- !scope="col" |Name !scope="col" class="unsortable"| Image !scope="col" |Agency !scope="col" |Location !scope="col" |Date established !scope="col" |Area (2017){{cite web |url=https://www.fs.fed.us/land/staff/lar/LAR2017/Table-18-NationalMonumentAreasbyState.pdf |title=Table 18 - National Monument Areas by State |author= |date=Sep 30, 2017 |website=Land Areas Report (LAR)–as of September 30, 2017 |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |access-date=Feb 3, 2018 |quote=}}{{cite web |url=https://irma.nps.gov/Stats/FileDownload/11383 |title= Listing of Acreage (Summary) |author= |date=Sep 30, 2017 |website=NPS Stats |publisher=National Park Service |access-date=Feb 3, 2018 |quote=}} {{cite web |url=https://www.blm.gov/sites/blm.gov/files/PublicLandStatistics2016.pdf |title=Public Land Statistics 2016 |author= |date=May 2017 |website= |publisher=U.S. Department of the Interior • Bureau of Land Management |access-date=Feb 3, 2018 |quote="Table 5-2. National Monuments within the National Landscape Conservation System as of September 30, 2016"}} {{cite web |url=https://www.fws.gov/refuges/land/PDF/2017_Annual_Report_of_Lands_Data_Tables.pdf |title= Statistical Data Tables for Fish & Wildlife Service Lands (as of 9/30/2017) |author= |date=Sep 30, 2017 |website= |publisher=U.S. Fish & Wildlife Service |access-date=Feb 3, 2018 |quote="Table 10. National Monuments"}} {{cite web |url=https://www.fs.fed.us/land/staff/lar/LAR2017/Table-19-NationalVolcanicMonumentAreabyState.pdf |title=Table 19 - National Volcanic Monument Areas by State |author= |date=Sep 30, 2017 |website=Land Areas Report (LAR)–as of September 30, 2017 |publisher=U.S. Forest Service |access-date=Feb 3, 2018 |quote=}} !scope="col" class="unsortable"|Description |- | [[Admiralty Island National Monument|Admiralty Island]] | [[File:Adis windfall harbor.jpg|200px]] | [[US Forest Service|USFS]] | [[Alaska]]
{{coord|57.64|-134.35|name=Admiralty Island|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1978|12|1}} | {{convert| 1019861|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Occupying most of [[Admiralty Island]], the 7th largest in the United States, this monument is part of [[Tongass National Forest]] in [[Southeast Alaska]]. The monument protects the densest known population of [[brown bear]] on Earth, along with habitat for the [[Sitka black-tailed deer]]. Most of the monument has been designated as the Kootznoowoo Wilderness, restricting future development. The [[Greens Creek mine]] lies within the monument.{{cite web|url=http://www.fs.fed.us/r10/tongass/districts/admiralty/|title=Admiralty Island National Monument |date=November 21, 2007|publisher=USDA Forest Service|accessdate=2009-01-17}} |- | [[African Burial Ground National Monument|African Burial Ground]] | [[File:African Burial Ground.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[New York (state)|New York]]
{{coord|40.7144|-74.0042|name=African Burial Ground|type:landmark}} | {{dts|2006|2|27}} | {{convert| 0.35|acre|km2|3|sortable=on}} | Re-discovered in 1991 during excavations for a new federal building, this former burial ground that contains the remains of more than 400 free and enslaved Africans buried during the 17th and 18th centuries was designated a [[National Historic Landmark]] memorial in 1993.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/afbg/|title=African Burial Ground National Monument|date=January 7, 2009|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-17}} |- | [[Agate Fossil Beds National Monument|Agate Fossil Beds]] | [[File:Agathe National Monument10.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[Nebraska]]
{{coord|42.416|-103.728|name=Agate Fossil Beds|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1997|6|14}} | {{convert| 3057.87|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | The valley of the [[Niobrara River]] is known for its large number of well-preserved [[Miocene]] mammal [[fossil]]s which date from about 20 million years ago.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/agfo/|title=Agate Fossil Beds National Monument|date=August 23, 2007|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-17}} |- | [[Agua Fria National Monument|Agua Fria]] | [[File:Agfr aguafriariver.jpg|200px]] | [[Bureau of Land Management|BLM]] | [[Arizona]]
{{coord|34.15|-112.08|name=Agua Fria|type:landmark}} | {{dts|2000|1|11}} | {{convert| 70980|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Located around the canyon of the [[Agua Fria River]], it contains more than 450 distinct [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] structures, including large [[pueblo]]s with more than 100 rooms.{{cite web|url=http://www.blm.gov/az/st/en/prog/blm_special_areas/natmon/afria.2.html|title=Agua Fria NM|date=February 21, 2008|publisher=Bureau of Land Management|accessdate=2009-01-17|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081020070301/http://www.blm.gov/az/st/en/prog/blm_special_areas/natmon/afria.2.html|archivedate=October 20, 2008|df=}} |- | [[Alibates Flint Quarries National Monument|Alibates Flint Quarries]] | [[File:Alfl alibates 20060726164737.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[Texas]]
{{coord|35.57|-101.67|name=Alibates Flint Quarries|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1965|8|21}} | {{convert| 1370.97 |acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Alibates was the quarry site for high-quality, rainbow-hued [[flint]] that was distributed throughout the [[Great Plains]] in [[pre-Columbian]] times. It is jointly operated with the [[Lake Meredith National Recreation Area]] and includes the ruins of several Plains Village Indian dwellings.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/alfl/|title=Alibates Flint Quarries National Monument|date=February 29, 2008|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-17}} |- | [[Aniakchak National Monument and Preserve|Aniakchak]] | [[File:Aniakchak-caldera alaska.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[Alaska]]
{{coord|56.9|-158.15|name=Anikchak|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1978|12|1}} | {{convert| 137176|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | [[Mount Aniakchak]], which erupted 3,500 years ago, and the surrounding region make up one of the least visited [[National Park Service|NPS]] sites. Surprise Lake, within the volcano's {{convert|6|mi|km|adj=on}} wide, {{convert|2500|ft|m|adj=on}} deep [[caldera]], is the source of the [[Aniakchak River]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/ania/|title=Aniakchak National Monument and Preserve|date=September 11, 2008|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-17}} |- | [[Aztec Ruins National Monument|Aztec Ruins]] | [[File:Aztec nima1.JPG|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[New Mexico]]
{{coord|36.83|-107.00|name=Aztec Ruins|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1923|1|24}} | {{convert| 318.4|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | The ruins contain [[Puebloan peoples|Pueblo]] structures from the 11th to 13th centuries with more than 400 masonry rooms which were misidentified by early American settlers as [[Aztec]]. It has been included in the Chaco Culture [[World Heritage Site]], which also includes [[Chaco Culture National Historical Park]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/azru/|title=Aztec Ruins National Monument|date=March 4, 2008|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-17}} |- | [[Bandelier National Monument|Bandelier]] | [[File:Bandelier Kiva.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[New Mexico]]
{{coord|35.78|-106.27|name=Bandelier|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1916|2|11}} | {{convert| 33676.67|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | A [[Historic district (United States)|historic district]], Bandelier contains Frijoles Canyon, which contains [[Ancestral Pueblo]] homes, [[kiva]]s, [[rock painting]]s and [[petroglyph]]s.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/band/|title=Bandelier National Monument|date=January 6, 2009|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-17}}{{cite web|url=http://tps.cr.nps.gov/nhl/detail.cfm?ResourceId=2023&ResourceType=District |title=Bandelier CCC Historic District |work=National Historic Landmarks Program |publisher=National Park Service |accessdate=2009-01-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120105061255/http://tps.cr.nps.gov/nhl/detail.cfm?ResourceId=2023&ResourceType=District |archivedate=2012-01-05 |df= }} |- | [[Basin and Range National Monument|Basin and Range]] | [[File:Basin & Range NM (22283541866).jpg|200px]] | [[Bureau of Land Management|BLM]] | [[Nevada]]
{{coord|37.9|-115.4|name=Basin and Range|type:landmark}} | {{dts|2015|7|10}} | {{convert| 703585|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Remote, undeveloped mountains and valleys in [[Lincoln County, Nevada|Lincoln]] and [[Nye County, Nevada|Nye]] counties in southeastern Nevada{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/obama-to-create-new-national-monuments-in-texas-california-nevada/|title=Obama to create new national monuments in Texas, California, Nevada|publisher=CBS|accessdate=2015-07-10}} |- | [[Bears Ears National Monument|Bears Ears]] | [[File:House on Fire Ruin.jpg|200px]] | [[Bureau of Land Management|BLM]], [[US Forest Service|USFS]] | [[Utah]]
{{coord|37.63|-109.86|name=Bears Ears National Monument|type:landmark}} | {{dts|2016|12|28}} | {{convert| 201876|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}}{{cite web|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/presidential-proclamation-modifying-bears-ears-national-monument/|title=Presidential Proclamation Modifying the Bears Ears National Monument|last=Trump|first=Donald|website=whitehouse.gov|publisher=[[White House Office of the Press Secretary]]|location=Washington, D.C.|date=December 4, 2017|access-date=February 3, 2018}} | Twin buttes, sandstone canyons, desert mesas, forested highlands, rock art, ancient cliff dwellings, ceremonial kivas[https://www.doi.gov/pressreleases/secretaries-jewell-vilsack-applaud-presidents-designation-new-national-monuments-utah Secretaries Jewell, Vilsack Applaud President’s Designation of New National Monuments in Utah and Nevada], U.S. Department of the Interior, news release, Dec. 28, 2016 |- | [[Belmont-Paul Women's Equality National Monument|Belmont-Paul Women's Equality]] | [[File:Sewall-Belmont House.JPG|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[District of Columbia]]
{{coord|38.89|-77.00|name=Belmont-Paul Women's Equality|type:landmark}} | {{dts|2016|4|12}} | {{convert| 0.34|acre|km2|3|sortable=on}} | Home of the [[National Woman's Party]] since 1929, it was the home where party leader [[Alice Paul]] and others lived and worked.{{cite news|last=Eilperin|first=Juliet|title=A new memorial to tell 'the story of a century of courageous activism by American women'|work=The Washington Post|date=April 12, 2016|accessdate=April 12, 2016|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-politics/wp/2016/04/11/obama-to-designate-a-national-monument-in-d-c-to-honor-womens-equality-tuesday/}}{{cite web|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2016/04/12/presidential-proclamation-establishment-belmont-paul-womens-equality|title=Presidential Proclamation -- Establishment of the Belmont-Paul Women’s Equality National Monument|publisher=The White House|accessdate=2016-04-12}} |- | [[Berryessa Snow Mountain National Monument|Berryessa Snow Mountain]] | [[File:Cache Creek wilderness.jpg|200px]] | [[United States Forest Service|USFS]], [[Bureau of Land Management|BLM]] | [[California]]
{{coord|39.22|-122.77|name=Berryessa Snow Mountain|type:landmark}} | {{dts|2015|7|10}} | {{convert| 330780|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Fewer than {{convert|100|mi|km}} from the [[San Francisco Bay Area]], Berryessa Snow Mountain protects part of the [[California Coast Range]], one of the most biodiverse regions in the state, home to elk, osprey, river otters, half the state’s dragonfly species, and California’s second-largest population of wintering bald eagles.{{cite web|url=http://wilderness.org/article/berryessa-snow-mountain-campaign/|title=Berryessa Snow Mountain|website=wilderness.org|accessdate=July 10, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150712143014/http://wilderness.org/article/berryessa-snow-mountain-campaign#|archive-date=2015-07-12|dead-url=yes|df=}} |- |[[Birmingham Civil Rights National Monument|Birmingham Civil Rights]] |[[File:A.G. Gaston Motel, Birmingham, Alabama LCCN2010636968.tif|200px]] |[[National Park Service|NPS]] |[[Alabama]]
{{coord|33.513|-86.815|name=Birmingham Civil Rights|type:landmark}} |{{dts|2017|1|12}} | {{convert| 0.88|acre|km2|3|sortable=on}} |Preserves the [[A. G. Gaston]] Motel, a historic site related to the [[civil rights movement]] in [[Birmingham, Alabama]].{{cite news|last1=Salama|first1=Vivian|title=Obama Names 3 National Monuments Honoring Civil Rights|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/wireStory/obama-names-national-monuments-honoring-civil-rights-44745286|accessdate=12 January 2017|agency=ABC News|date=12 January 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170113170148/http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/wireStory/obama-names-national-monuments-honoring-civil-rights-44745286#|archivedate=2017-01-13|deadurl=yes|df=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.nps.gov/bicr/learn/proclamation.htm|title=Presidential Proclamation - Birmingham Civil Rights National Monument|date=January 13, 2017|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=November 4, 2018}} |- | [[Booker T. Washington National Monument|Booker T. Washington]] | [[File:Booker T. Washington National Monument.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[Virginia]]
{{coord|37.123|-79.766|name=Booker T. Washington|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1956|4|2}} | {{convert| 239.01|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | The Booker T. Washington National Monument preserves portions of the {{convert|207|acre|km2|adj=on}} [[tobacco]] farm on which educator and civil rights leader [[Booker T. Washington]] was born into slavery on April 5, 1856. The site contains replicas of the house Washington was born in, a smokehouse, a blacksmith shed, a tobacco barn, and a horse barn.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/bowa/|title=Booker T. Washington National Monument|date=July 4, 2008|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-17}} |- | [[Browns Canyon National Monument|Browns Canyon]] | [[File:Browns Canyon National Monument (15740559230).jpg|200px]] | [[Bureau of Land Management|BLM]], [[United States Forest Service|USFS]] | [[Colorado]]
{{coord|38.615|-106.059|name=Browns Canyon|type:landmark}} | {{dts|2015|2|19}} | {{convert| 21604|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Protects 21,500 acres of steep cliffs and colorful rock outcroppings overlooking the [[Arkansas River]] in [[Chaffee County, Colorado]], as well as the area's rich native history.{{cite web|url=http://www.blm.gov/wo/st/en/info/newsroom/2015/february/nr_02_19_2015.html|title=Browns Canyon National Monument|date=February 19, 2015|publisher=Bureau of Land Management|accessdate=2015-02-19|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150220092541/http://www.blm.gov/wo/st/en/info/newsroom/2015/february/nr_02_19_2015.html|archivedate=February 20, 2015|df=}} |- | [[Buck Island Reef National Monument|Buck Island Reef]] | [[File:BuckIslandReedNM.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[United States Virgin Islands|US Virgin Islands]]
{{coord|17.79|-64.62|name=Buck Island Reef|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1961|12|28}} | {{convert| 19015.47|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Most of this {{convert|19000|acre|km2|adj=on}} monument is underwater, containing a large [[coral reef|elkhorn coral barrier reef]] that provides cover for a great variety of reef fish, [[sea turtle]]s and [[least tern]]s. It is based around Buck Island, an uninhabited {{convert|176|acre|km2|adj=on}} island.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/bowa/|title=Buck Island Reef National Monument|date=August 23, 2007|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-17}} |- | [[Cabrillo National Monument|Cabrillo]] | [[File:Cabrillo-Szmurlo.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[California]]
{{coord|32.67|-117.24|name=Cabrillo|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1913|10|14}} | {{convert| 159.94|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | This monument commemorates the landing of [[Juan Rodríguez Cabrillo]] at [[San Diego Bay]] on September 28, 1542, which was the first European expedition on what later became the west coast of the U.S. The monument includes a statue of Cabrillo and 20th-century [[coastal artillery]] batteries built to protect the harbor of San Diego from enemy warships.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/cabr/|title=Cabrillo National Monument|date=August 4, 2008|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-17}} |- | [[California Coastal National Monument|California Coastal]] | [[File:California coastal nm.jpg|200px]] | [[Bureau of Land Management|BLM]] | [[California]]
{{coord|36.89|-122.18|name=California Coastal|type:landmark}} | {{dts|2000|1|11}} | {{convert| 2628|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | This monument ensures the protection of all islets, reefs and rock outcroppings from the coast of [[California]] to a distance of {{convert|12|nmi|km}}, along the entire {{convert|840|mi|km|adj=on}} long California coastline.{{cite web|url=http://www.blm.gov/pgdata/content/ca/en/prog/blm_special_areas/nm/ccnm.html |title=California Coastal National Monument |date=January 5, 2009 |publisher=Bureau of Land Management |accessdate=2009-01-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090115171809/http://www.blm.gov/pgdata/content/ca/en/prog/blm_special_areas/nm/ccnm.html |archivedate=January 15, 2009 |df= }} |- |[[Camp Nelson National Monument|Camp Nelson]] |[[File:Camp_Nelson_landscape.JPG|200px]] |[[National Park Service|NPS]] |[[Kentucky]]
{{coord|37.78|-84.60|name=Camp Nelson|type:landmark}} |{{dts|2018|10|26}} |{{convert|373|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Established in 1863 as a depot for the Union Army during the Civil War, Camp Nelson became a large recruitment center for African American Union soldiers: a key site of emancipation for those soldiers and a refugee camp for their familieshttps://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/presidential-proclamation-establishment-camp-nelson-national-monument/. |- | [[Canyon de Chelly National Monument|Canyon de Chelly]] | [[File:Canyon de Chelly, Navajo.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[Arizona]]
{{coord|36.13|-109.47|name=Canyon de Chelly|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1931|4|1}} | {{convert| 83840|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Located within the boundaries of the [[Navajo Nation]], it preserves the valleys and rims of the canyons of de Chelly, del Muerto, and Monument, all of which are Navajo Tribal Trust Lands.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/cach/|title=Canyon de Chelly National Monument|date=June 4, 2008|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-19}} |- | [[Canyons of the Ancients National Monument|Canyons of the Ancients]] | [[File:Canyons of the Ancients National Monument.jpg|200px]] | [[Bureau of Land Management|BLM]] | [[Colorado]]
