{{coord|37.37|-109|name=Canyon of the Ancients|type:landmark}} | {{dts|2000|6|9}} | {{convert| 176370|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Surrounding [[Hovenweep National Monument]], it preserves and protects more than 6,000 [[archaeology|archeological]] sites, the largest concentration in the U.S.{{cite web|url=http://www.blm.gov/co/st/en/nm/canm.html|title=Canyons of the Ancients National Monument|date=November 25, 2008|publisher=Bureau of Land Management|accessdate=2009-01-19|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090123142844/http://www.blm.gov/co/st/en/nm/canm.html|archivedate=January 23, 2009|df=}} |- | [[Cape Krusenstern National Monument|Cape Krusenstern]] | [[File:CapeKrusensternNM.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[Alaska]]
{{coord|67.41|-163.50|name=Cape Krusenstern|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1978|12|1}} | {{convert| 649096.15|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Co-located with the [[National Historic Landmark District|NHLD]] Cape Krusenstern Archeological District, this coastal plain contains large [[lagoons]] and rolling hills of [[limestone]]. The bluffs record thousands of years of change in the shorelines of the [[Chukchi Sea]], as well as evidence of some 9,000 years of human habitation.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/cakr/|title=Cape Krusenstern National Monument|date=July 2, 2008|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-19}} |- | [[Capulin Volcano National Monument|Capulin Volcano]] | [[File:Capulin 1980 tde00005.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[New Mexico]]
{{coord|36.79|-103.96|name=Capulin Volcano|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1916|8|9}} | {{convert| 792.84|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Capulin is an extinct [[volcanic cone#Cinder cone|cinder cone]] [[volcano]] that is approximately 59,000 years old and part of the [[Raton-Clayton Volcanic Field]]. The crater is {{convert|400|ft|m}} deep and its rim is more than {{convert|1500|ft|m}} in diameter.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/cavo/|title=Capulin Volcano National Monument|date=October 29, 2008|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-19}} |- | [[Carrizo Plain]] | [[File:RockCove-CarrizoPlain.jpg|200px]] | [[Bureau of Land Management|BLM]] | [[California]]
{{coord|35.16|-119.75|name=Carrizo Plain|type:landmark}} | {{dts|2001|1|12}} | {{convert| 211045|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Carrizo Plain is the largest single [[Indigenous (ecology)|native]] [[grassland]] remaining in California. It contains part of the [[San Andreas Fault]] and is surrounded by the [[Temblor Range]] and the [[Caliente Range]]. At the center of the plain is [[Soda Lake (San Luis Obispo County)|Soda Lake]], which is near [[Painted Rock (San Luis Obispo County, California)|Painted Rock]].{{cite web|url=http://www.blm.gov/ca/st/en/fo/bakersfield/Programs/carrizo.html |title=Carrizo Plain National Monument |date=December 22, 2008 |publisher=Bureau of Land Management |accessdate=2009-01-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090126015543/http://www.blm.gov/ca/st/en/fo/bakersfield/Programs/carrizo.html |archivedate=January 26, 2009 |df= }} |- | [[Casa Grande Ruins National Monument|Casa Grande Ruins]] | [[File:Casagrande1.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[Arizona]]
{{coord|32.99|-111.54|name=Casa Grande Ruins|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1918|8|3}} | {{convert| 472.5|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | This monument preserves a group of structures surrounded by a compound wall in the [[Gila River|Gila Valley]] that were built in the early 13th century. They were inhabited by the [[Hohokam]] people until they were abandoned in the mid-15th century.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/cagr/|title=Casa Grande Ruins|date=January 8, 2009|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-17}} |- | [[Cascade–Siskiyou National Monument|Cascade–Siskiyou]] | [[File:Sambucus caerulea 8012.jpg|200px]] | [[Bureau of Land Management|BLM]] | [[Oregon]], [[California]]
{{coord|42.08|-122.46|name=Cascade-Siskiyou|type:landmark}} | {{dts|2000|6|9}} | {{convert| 65341|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | One of the most diverse [[ecosystem]]s found in the [[Cascade Range]], it has more than 100 dwelling and root-gathering sites belonging to the [[Modoc people|Modoc]], [[Klamath people|Klamath]], and [[Shasta (tribe)|Shasta]] tribes.{{cite web|url=http://www.blm.gov/ca/st/en/fo/bakersfield/Programs/carrizo.html |title=Cascade–Siskiyou National Monument |publisher=Bureau of Land Management |accessdate=2009-01-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090126015543/http://www.blm.gov/ca/st/en/fo/bakersfield/Programs/carrizo.html |archivedate=2009-01-26 |df= }} |- | [[Castillo de San Marcos]] | [[File:Fort2.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[Florida]]
{{coord|29.898|-81.311|name=Castillo de San Marcos|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1924|10|15}} | {{convert| 19.38|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | This Spanish fort near [[St. Augustine, Florida|St. Augustine]], called Fort Marion when first protected, served for 205 years under four different flags. Built in 1672, it was involved in sieges with the British while under Spanish command, the [[American Revolution]] under Britain, the [[American Civil War|Civil War]] under the [[Confederate States of America|Confederacy]], and the [[Seminole Wars]] and the [[Spanish–American War]] under the United States.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/casa/|title=Castillo de San Marcos National Monument|date=March 4, 2008|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-19}} |- | [[Castle Clinton]] | [[File:Castleclinton.JPG|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[New York (state)|New York]]
{{coord|40.7036|-74.0169|name=Castle Clinton|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1946|8|12}} | {{convert| 1|acre|km2|3|sortable=on}} | A circular sandstone [[fort]] built in 1811 at the southern tip of [[Manhattan]] to protect [[New York City]] from the British, Castle Clinton is now located in [[Battery Park (New York)|Battery Park]]. It later became a [[beer garden]], a theater, the first immigration station (predating [[Ellis Island]]), and a public [[aquarium]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/cacl/|title=Castle Clinton National Monument|date=November 5, 2008|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-19}} |- | [[Castle Mountains National Monument|Castle Mountains]] | [[File:Castle Mountains and Joshua Trees.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[California]]
{{coord|35.25|-115.11|name=Castle Mountains|type:landmark}} | {{dts|2016|2|12}} | {{convert| 21025.5|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Castle Mountains represents some of the most unique elements of the Mojave Desert. Nestled between the Nevada state line and Mojave National Preserve, the nearly 21,000 acres of Castle Mountains boasts Joshua tree forests, unbroken natural landscapes, rare desert grasslands, and rich human history.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/camo/|title=Castle Mountains National Monument|date=|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2016-02-12}}{{cite web|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2016/02/12/fact-sheet-president-obama-designate-new-national-monuments-california|title=President Obama to Designate New National Monuments in the California Desert|date=|publisher=The White House|accessdate=2016-02-12}} |- | [[Cedar Breaks National Monument|Cedar Breaks]] | [[File:Cedarbreaksnationalmonument.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[Utah]]
{{coord|37.63|-112.85|name=Cedar Breaks|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1933|8|22}} | {{convert| 6154.6|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | A natural [[amphitheater]] canyon similar to formations at [[Bryce Canyon National Park]], it stretches over {{convert|3|mi|km}} and is more than {{convert|2000|ft|m}} deep.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/cebr/|title=Cedar Breaks National Monument|date=December 19, 2008|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-19}} |- | [[César E. Chávez National Monument|César E. Chávez]] | [[File:2009-0726-CA-NationalChavezCenter.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[California]]
{{coord|35.2273|-118.5614|name=Cesar E. Chavez|type:landmark}} | {{dts|2012|10|8}} | {{convert| 116.56|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | This monument commemorates the life and work of labor leader and civil right activist [[Cesar Chavez]]. Called La Paz, the site was Chavez's home for about 20 years, and his gravesite is on the premises. It is also the location of the headquarters of [[United Farm Workers]], which was founded by Chavez.{{cite web|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2012/10/01/president-obama-establish-c-sar-e-ch-vez-national-monument|title=President Obama to Establish César E. Chávez National Monument |date=October 1, 2012|publisher=White House|accessdate=2012-10-08}} |- | [[Charles Young Buffalo Soldiers National Monument|Charles Young Buffalo Soldiers]] | [[File:Colonel Charles Young House, front and western side.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[Ohio]]
{{coord|39.7072|-83.8903|name=Charles Young Buffalo Soldiers|type:landmark}} | {{dts|2013|3|25}} | {{convert| 59.66|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Charles Young was the first African American to reach the rank of colonel in the US Army. He was also the first national park superintendent, of Sequoia and General Grant National Parks and a professor at [[Wilberforce University]]. His home at Wilberforce is a museum commemorating his life.{{cite web|title=President Obama Designates Five New National Monuments|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2013/03/25/president-obama-designates-five-new-national-monuments|publisher=The White House|accessdate=25 March 2013}} |- | [[Chimney Rock National Monument|Chimney Rock]] | [[File:View of Chimney Rock Colorado.JPG|200px]] | [[United States Forest Service|USFS]] | [[Colorado]]
{{coord|37.1917|-107.3064|name=Chimney Rock|type:landmark}} | {{dts|2012|9|21}} | {{convert| 4724|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | The jewel of [[San Juan National Forest]], the site was once home to the ancestors of the modern Pueblos. Roughly 1,000 years ago, the Ancestral Pueblo People built more than 200 homes and ceremonial buildings high above the valley floor.{{cite web|url=http://www.fs.usda.gov/recarea/sanjuan/recarea/?recid=42806|title=Chimney Rock National Monument|date=September 21, 2012|publisher=USDA Forest Service|accessdate=2012-09-21}} |- | [[Chiricahua National Monument|Chiricahua]] | [[File:Chiricahua balanced rock.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[Arizona]]
{{coord|32.02|-109.35|name= Chiricahua|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1924|4|18}} | {{convert| 12024.73|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | These pillars of [[rhyolite tuff]] are the eroded remains of an immense [[volcanic]] eruption that shook the region some 27 million years ago. It was called the Land of the Standing-Up Rocks by the Apache.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/chir/|title=Capulin Chiricahua National Monument|date=May 19, 2008|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-19}} |- | [[Colorado National Monument|Colorado]] | [[File:Colorado national monument 20030920 130827 2.1504x1000.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[Colorado]]
{{coord|39.04|-108.69|name=Colorado|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1911|5|24}} | {{convert| 20536.39|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Monument Canyon runs the width of the park and includes rock formations formed by erosion. The monument includes {{convert|20500|acre|km2}} of semi-desert land high on the [[Colorado Plateau]] and has a wide range of wildlife including [[pinyon pine]]s, [[juniper]] trees, [[raven]]s, [[jay]]s, [[desert bighorn sheep]], and [[coyote]]s as well as a range of recreational activities.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/colm/|title=Colorado National Monument|date=January 18, 2008|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-19}} |- | [[Craters of the Moon National Monument and Preserve|Craters of the Moon]] | [[File:Scoria field at Craters of the Moon NM-750px.JPG|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]], [[Bureau of Land Management|BLM]] | [[Idaho]]
{{coord|43.42|-113.52|name=Craters of the Moon|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1924|5|2}} | {{convert| 53437.64|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | One of the best preserved [[flood basalt]] areas in the continental U.S. contains three lava fields along the Great Rift of Idaho as well as the world's deepest open [[rift]] cracks and other volcanic features.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/crmo/|title=Craters of the Moon National Monument and Preserve|date=January 10, 2009|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-19}}{{cite web|url=http://www.blm.gov/id/st/en/fo/shoshone/special_areas/Craters.html |title=Craters of the Moon National Monument |date=November 4, 2008 |publisher=Bureau of Land Management |accessdate=2009-02-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090201012722/http://www.blm.gov/id/st/en/fo/shoshone/special_areas/Craters.html |archivedate=February 1, 2009 |df= }} |- | [[Devils Postpile National Monument|Devils Postpile]] | [[File:Devils postpile NM.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[California]]
{{coord|37.50|-119.08|name=Devils Postpile|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1911|7|6}} | {{convert| 800.19|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Once part of Yosemite National Park, this monument is a dark cliff of [[columnar basalt]] created by a lava flow at least 100,000 years ago. It also has the {{convert|101|ft|m|adj=on}}-high Rainbow Falls.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/depo/|title=Devils Postpile National Monument|date=October 31, 2008|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-19}} |- | [[Devils Tower National Monument|Devils Tower]] | [[File:Devils Tower CROP.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[Wyoming]]
{{coord|44.59|-104.72|name=Devils Tower|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1906|9|24}} | {{convert| 1347.21|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | The tower is a [[monolith]]ic [[igneous rock|igneous]] [[intrusion]] of [[volcanic neck]] rising dramatically {{convert|1267|ft|m}} above the surrounding terrain. Proclaimed by Theodore Roosevelt, this was the first national monument.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/deto/|title=Devils Tower National Monument|date=October 3, 2008|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-19}} |- | [[Dinosaur National Monument|Dinosaur]] | [[File:DNM Morrison.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[Colorado]], [[Utah]]
{{coord|40.53|-108.98|name=Dinosaur|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1915|10|4}} | {{convert| 210281.92|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | This [[sandstone]] and [[conglomerate (geology)|conglomerate]] bed, known as the [[Morrison Formation]], was formed in the [[Jurassic]] Period and contains fossils of dinosaurs including [[Allosaurus]] and various long-neck and long-tail sauropods.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/dino/|title=Dinosaur National Monument|date=January 18, 2009|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-19}} |- | [[Effigy Mounds National Monument|Effigy Mounds]] | [[File:Effigy Mounds Iowa Sny Magill.JPG|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[Iowa]]
{{coord|43.09|-91.19|name=Effigy Mounds|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1949|10|25}} | {{convert| 2526.39|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | This monument preserves three prehistoric sites with 206 prehistoric [[Mound builder (people)|mounds]], notable for 31 unusual mounds in the shape of mammals, birds, or reptiles.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/efmo/|title=Effigy Mounds National Monument|date=January 15, 2009|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-19}} |- | [[El Malpais National Monument|El Malpais]] | [[File:ElMalpaisLava.JPG|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[New Mexico]]
{{coord|34.88|-108.05|name=El Malpais|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1987|12|31}} | {{convert| 114347.11|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | An extremely rough, rugged [[lava]] flow covers much of the park, filling a large basin rimmed by higher sandstone that forms large, wind-carved bluffs. It has [[lava tube]] caves that stretch over {{convert|17|mi|km}} and the Cebolla Wilderness, a forested rimrock area that features prehistoric rock art and the Zuni-Acoma Trail, an ancient Pueblo trade route.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/elma/|title=El Malpais National Monument|date=October 21, 2009|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-19}} |- | [[El Morro National Monument|El Morro]] | [[File:Elmo-bluff.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[New Mexico]]
{{coord|35.04|-108.35|name=El Morro|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1906|12|8}} | {{convert| 1278.72|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | On the site of an ancient east-west trail is a great sandstone promontory with a pool of water at its base. There are inscriptions from the 17th century as well as older [[petroglyph]]s made by the [[Ancestral Puebloans]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/elmo/|title=El Morro National Monument|date=October 21, 2008|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-19}} |- | [[Florissant Fossil Beds National Monument|Florissant Fossil Beds]] | [[File:Florisant.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[Colorado]]
{{coord|38.92|-105.27|name=Florissant Fossil beds|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1969|8|20}} | {{convert| 5998.09|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Huge petrified [[Sequoia sempervirens|redwoods]] and incredibly detailed [[fossil]]s of ancient insects and plants reveal a very different landscape in [[Colorado]] of almost 35 million years ago in the [[Eocene]] age.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/flfo/|title=Florissant Fossil Beds National Monument|date=December 16, 2008|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-19}} |- | [[Fort Frederica National Monument|Fort Frederica]] | [[File:FortFredBarracks.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]]
{{coord|31.224|-81.393|name=Fort Frederica|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1936|5|26}} | {{convert| 284.49|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Built by [[James Oglethorpe]] between 1736 and 1748, these remnants of a fort and town protected the southern boundary of the British colony of [[Province of Georgia|Georgia]] from [[Spain|Spanish]] raids. It was a few miles from the site of the [[Battle of Bloody Marsh]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/fofr/|title=Fort Frederica National Monument|date=November 12, 2008|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-19}} |- | [[Fort Matanzas National Monument|Fort Matanzas]] | [[File:Fortwestern.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[Florida]]
{{coord|29.715|-81.239|name=Fort Matanzas|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1924|10|15}} | {{convert| 300.11|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | This 1740 Spanish fort guarded [[Matanzas Inlet]], the southern mouth of the [[Matanzas River]], which allowed access to [[St. Augustine, Florida|St. Augustine]]. The monument is managed in conjunction with [[Castillo de San Marcos]] National Monument and also protects {{convert|100|acre|km2}} of [[salt marsh]] and [[barrier island]]s.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/foma/|title=Fort Matanzas National Monument|date=February 29, 2008|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-19}} |- | [[Fort McHenry]] | [[File:FtMcHenryEntrance.JPG|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[Maryland]]
{{coord|39.263|-76.579|name=Fort McHenry|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1925|3|3}} | {{convert| 43.26|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | The only place designated a national monument and historic shrine, Fort McHenry is a [[Star fort|star-shaped fort]] best known for its role in the [[War of 1812]] when it successfully defended [[Inner Harbor|Baltimore Harbor]] from an attack by the [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland|British]] [[Royal Navy|navy]]. It inspired [[Francis Scott Key]] to write "[[The Star-Spangled Banner]]".{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/fomc/|title=Fort McHenry National Monument|date=January 5, 2009|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-19}} |- | [[Fort Monroe]] | [[File:Fort Monroe Aerial.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[Virginia]]
{{coord|37.004|-76.308|name=Fort Monroe|type:landmark}} | {{dts|2011|11|1}} | {{convert| 367.12|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Fort Monroe National Monument spans the American story from the 17th to the 21st centuries: [[Captain John Smith]]'s journeys, a haven of freedom for the enslaved during the Civil War, and a bastion of defense for the [[Chesapeake Bay]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/fomr/index.htm|title=Fort Monroe National Monument|date=November 1, 2011|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2011-11-01}} |- | [[Fort Ord National Monument|Fort Ord]] | [[File:Fort Ord NM (9302539654).jpg|200px]] | [[Bureau of Land Management|BLM]] | [[California]]
{{coord|36.639167|-121.735278|name=Fort Ord|type:landmark}} | {{dts|2012|4|20}} | {{convert| 14658|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Fort Ord was an Army post from 1917 to 1994. It now has recreational trails and various wildlife. |- | [[Fort Pulaski National Monument|Fort Pulaski]] | [[File:FtPulaskiInside.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]]
{{coord|32.027|-80.890|name=Fort Pulaski|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1924|10|15}} | {{convert| 5623.1|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | In 1862 during the [[American Civil War]], the [[Union Army]] successfully tested a [[rifling|rifled]] [[cannon]] against the defending Confederates, rendering brick fortifications obsolete. Fort Pulaski was also used as a [[prisoner-of-war camp]] during the war. The national monument includes most of [[Cockspur Island]] (containing the fort) and all of adjacent McQueens Island.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/fopu/|title=Fort Pulaski National Monument|date=December 26, 2008|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-19}} |- | [[Fort Stanwix]] | [[File:Fost areal image007.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[New York (state)|New York]]
{{coord|43.218|-75.459|name=Fort Stanwix|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1935|8|21}} | {{convert| 15.52|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Fort Stanwix guarded a strategic 18th century [[portage]] known as the [[Oneida Carry|Oneida Carrying Place]]. It was built during the [[French and Indian War]] (1754–1763). The fort successfully resisted the [[Siege of Fort Stanwix|1777 siege]] by a British invasion army during the [[Saratoga campaign]] of the [[American Revolutionary War]]. Erased by the development of [[Rome, New York]], it was rebuilt as a national monument in the late 1970s.{{cite web |url=https://www.nps.gov/fost/learn/historyculture/index.htm |title=History & Culture - Fort Stanwix National Monument |date= |publisher=National Park Service |accessdate=2016-08-25}} |- | [[Fort Sumter National Monument|Fort Sumter]] | [[File:FortSumter2009.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[South Carolina]]
{{coord|32.752|-79.874|name=Fort Sumter|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1948|4|28}} | {{convert| 234.74|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Fort Sumter is a [[Seacoast Defense (US)#Third system|Third System]] masonry coastal fortification located in [[Charleston, South Carolina|Charleston]] harbor, [[South Carolina]]. It is best known as the site where the shots initiating the [[American Civil War]] were fired, at the [[Battle of Fort Sumter]]. Nearby [[Fort Moultrie]] is a unit of this monument; it was made of [[Cabbage palmetto|palmetto]] logs and inspired the [[Flag of South Carolina|flag]] and nickname (Palmetto State) of [[South Carolina]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/fosu/|title=Fort Sumter National Monument|date=January 8, 2009|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-19}} |- | [[Fort Union National Monument|Fort Union]] | [[File:Fortunion.JPG|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[New Mexico]]
{{coord|35.925|-105.009|name=Fort Union|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1956|4|5}} | {{convert| 720.6|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | A frontier military post and supply depot in the late 19th century, it sat at the intersection of the Mountain and Cimarron Branches of the old [[Santa Fe Trail]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/foun/|title=Fort Union National Monument|date=September 3, 2008|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-19}} |- | [[Fossil Butte National Monument|Fossil Butte]] | [[File:FossilButte.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[Wyoming]]
{{coord|41.86|-110.77|name=Fossil Butte|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1972|10|23}} | {{convert| 8198|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Fossil Butte preserves the 50-million-year-old [[Green River Formation|Green River]] lake beds, the best [[paleontology|paleontological]] record of [[tertiary]] aquatic communities in North America. Fossils including fish, alligators, bats, turtles, dog-sized horses, insects, and many other species of plants and animals suggest that the region was a low, subtropical, freshwater basin when the sediments accumulated, over about a 2-million-year period.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/foubu/|title=Fossil Butte National Monument|date=November 4, 2008|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-19}} |- |[[Freedom Riders National Monument|Freedom Riders]] |[[File:Former Greyhound station, Anniston, Alabama.jpg|200px]] |[[National Park Service|NPS]] |[[Alabama]]
{{coord|33.658|-85.831|name=Freedom Riders|type:landmark}} |{{dts|2017|1|12}} | {{convert| 5.96|acre|km2|2|sortable=on}} | Preserves two sites related to the [[Freedom Riders]] in and near [[Anniston, Alabama]] during the [[civil rights movement]]—a former Greyhound bus station in the town and the site of a bus burning incident outside town.{{cite web|url=https://www.nps.gov/frri/learn/proclamation.htm|title=Presidential Proclamation - Freedom Riders National Monument|date=January 13, 2017|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=November 4, 2018}} |- | [[George Washington Birthplace National Monument|George Washington Birthplace]] | [[File:Geo Washington birthplace.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[Virginia]]
{{coord|38.1861|-76.9305|name=George Washington's Birthplace|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1930|1|23}} | {{convert| 653.18|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Representative of 18th-century Virginia tobacco farms, this site is the birthplace and boyhood environment of [[George Washington]]. The entrance includes a Memorial Shaft [[obelisk]] of Vermont marble that is a one-tenth scale replica of the [[Washington Monument]] in Washington, D.C. Also within the monument are the historic birthplace home area, a kitchen house, and the Washington family burial ground.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/gewa/|title=George Washington Birthplace National Monument|date=March 26, 2008|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-19}} |- | [[George Washington Carver National Monument|George Washington Carver]] | [[File:George-washington-carver-nmon-2.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[Missouri]]
{{coord|36.986|-94.354|name=George Washington Carver|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1943|7|14}} | {{convert| 210|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | The site preserves [[Moses Carver]]'s farm, which was the boyhood home of [[George Washington Carver]], a scientist and educator who developed many uses for [[peanut]]s. It was the first national monument dedicated to an African-American and first to a non-president.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/gwca/|title=George Washington Carver National Monument|date=October 2, 2008|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-19}} |- | [[Giant Sequoia National Monument|Giant Sequoia]] |
[[File:Giant sequoia-national-monument-jason-hickey.jpg|160px]]
| [[US Forest Service|USFS]] | [[California]]
{{coord|36.04|-118.50|name=Giant Sequoia National Monument|type:landmark}} | {{dts|2000|4|15}} | {{convert| 352626|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | The monument includes 38 of the 39 [[giant sequoia]] groves in the [[Sequoia National Forest]], amounting to about half of the [[List of sequoia groves|sequoia groves]] currently in existence. This includes one of the [[List of largest giant sequoias|ten largest]] giant sequoias, the [[Boole (tree)|Boole Tree]]. Its two parts are around [[Kings Canyon National Park|Kings Canyon]] and [[Sequoia National Park]]s.{{cite web|url=http://www.fs.fed.us/r5/sequoia/|title=Sequoia National Forest|date=January 18, 2009|publisher=USDA Forest Service|accessdate=2009-01-19}} |- | [[Gila Cliff Dwellings National Monument|Gila Cliff Dwellings]] | [[File:GilaCliffDwellings NatlMonument.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[New Mexico]]
{{coord|33.24|-108.28|name=Gila Cliff Dwellings|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1907|11|16}} | {{convert| 533.13|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Located within the [[Gila Wilderness]], the people of the [[Mogollon culture]] lived in these [[Cliff-dwelling|cliff dwellings]] {{convert|180|ft|m}} above the canyon floor from the 1280s through the early 14th century. They lived in five caves with 46 rooms. Henry B. Ailman discovered them in 1878.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/gicl/|title=Gila Cliff Dwellings National Monument|date=September 8, 2008|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-19}} |- | [[Gold Butte National Monument|Gold Butte]] | [[File:Gold Butte National Monument 5.jpg|200px]] | [[Bureau of Land Management|BLM]] | [[Nevada]]
{{coord|36.281|-114.201|name=Gold Butte National Monument|type:landmark}} | {{dts|2016|12|28}} | {{convert| 296937|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://obamawhitehouse.archives.gov/the-press-office/2016/12/28/presidential-proclamation-establishment-gold-butte-national-monument |title=Presidential Proclamation -- Establishment of the Gold Butte National Monument |last=Obama |first=Barack |date=Dec 28, 2016 |website=obamawhitehouse.archives.gov |publisher=[[White House Office of the Press Secretary]]| location=Washington, D.C. |access-date=Feb 13, 2018 |quote=}} | Mojave Desert landscape of dramatic red sandstone, canyons, forested mountains, ancient rock art, rock shelters, roasting pits, and a mining ghost town |- | [[Governors Island National Monument|Governors Island]] | [[File:FortJay.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[New York (state)|New York]]
{{coord|40.691|-74.016|name=Governors Island|type:landmark}} | {{dts|2001|1|19}} | {{convert| 22.91|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | From 1783 to 1966, [[Governors Island]] in [[New York Harbor]] was an [[United States Army|Army]] post, and from 1966 to 1996 it was a [[United States Coast Guard|Coast Guard]] installation. Located on Governors Island are [[Castle Williams]] and [[Fort Jay]], which served as outposts to protect [[New York City]] from sea attack.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/gois/|title=Governors Island National Monument|date=October 24, 2008|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-19}} |- | [[Grand Canyon-Parashant National Monument|Grand Canyon-Parashant]] | [[File:Para slide1.jpg|200px]] | [[Bureau of Land Management|BLM]], [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[Arizona]]
{{coord|36.4|-113.7|name=Grand Canyon-Parashant|type:landmark}} | {{dts|2000|1|11}} | {{convert| 1021030|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Located on the northern rim of the [[Grand Canyon]], this diverse landscape includes an array of scientific and historic resources. About 20,000 of the monument's {{convert|1017000|acre|km2}} are also within [[Lake Mead National Recreation Area]]; Grand Canyon-Parashant is not considered an official NPS unit. There are no paved roads or visitor services.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/para/|title=Grand Canyon-Parashant National Monument|date=May 7, 2008|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-19}}{{cite web|url=http://www.blm.gov/az/st/en/prog/blm_special_areas/natmon/gcp.html|title=Grand Canyon-Parashant National Monument|date=April 28, 2008|publisher=Bureau of Land Management|accessdate=2009-02-03|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090131204043/http://www.blm.gov/az/st/en/prog/blm_special_areas/natmon/gcp.html|archivedate=January 31, 2009|df=}} |- | [[Grand Portage National Monument|Grand Portage]] | [[File:050820 GrandPortageNationalMonument.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[Minnesota]]
{{coord|47.96|-89.68|name=Grant Portage|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1960|1|27}} | {{convert| 709.97|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | The Grand Portage itself is an {{convert|8.5|mi|km|adj=on}} footpath which bypasses a set of waterfalls on the [[Pigeon River (Minnesota-Ontario)|Pigeon River]] near [[Lake Superior]]. The region was a vital [[trade route]] and center of [[fur trade]] activity as well as an Anishinaabeg [[Ojibwe]] heritage site.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/foun/|title=Grand Portage National Monument|date=July 14, 2008|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-19}} |- | [[Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monument|Grand Staircase-Escalante]] | [[File:-conservationlands15 Social Media Takeover, Feb 15th, What is a National Monument? (15924054253).jpg|200px]] | [[Bureau of Land Management|BLM]] | [[Utah]]
{{coord|37.4|-111.68|name=Grand Staircase-Escalante|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1996|9|18}} | {{convert| 1003863|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/presidential-proclamation-modifying-grand-staircase-escalante-national-monument/ |title=Presidential Proclamation Modifying the Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monument |last=Trump |first=Donald |date=Dec 4, 2017 | website=whitehouse.gov|publisher=[[White House Office of the Press Secretary]]|location=Washington, D.C.| access-date=Feb 13, 2018 |quote=}} | Preserving {{convert|1003863|acre|km2}}, the monument consists of the [[Grand Staircase]], the [[Kaiparowits Plateau]], and the [[Escalante River|Canyons of the Escalante]]. It is notable for its [[paleontology|paleontological]] finds and geology, and it was the first monument to be maintained by the [[Bureau of Land Management]].{{cite web|url=http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/fo/grand_staircase-escalante.html|title=Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monument|date=January 15, 2009|publisher=Bureau of Land Management|accessdate=2009-01-19|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090116120800/http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/fo/grand_staircase-escalante.html|archivedate=January 16, 2009|df=}} |- | [[Hagerman Fossil Beds National Monument|Hagerman Fossil Beds]] | [[File:HAFO FlowersRiver.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[Idaho]]
{{coord|42.79|-114.95|name=Hagerman Fossil Beds|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1988|11|18}} | {{convert| 4351.15|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | This monument contains the largest concentration of [[Hagerman horse]] fossils in North America. It protects the world's richest known fossil deposits from the late [[Pliocene]] epoch, 3.5 million years ago. These plants and animals represent the last glimpse of time that existed before the [[Ice Age]], and the earliest appearances of modern flora and fauna.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/hafo/|title=Hagerman Fossil Beds National Monument|date=January 6, 2009|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-19}} |- | [[Hanford Reach National Monument|Hanford Reach]] | [[File:Hare columbia-river.jpg|200px]] | [[U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service|FWS]], [[United States Department of Energy|DOE]] | [[Washington (U.S. state)|Washington]]
{{coord|46.48|-119.53|name=Hanford Reach|type:landmark}} | {{dts|2000|6|8}} | {{convert| 194450.93|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Created from what used to be the security buffer surrounding the [[Hanford Nuclear Reservation]], this area has been untouched by development or agriculture since 1943. The area is part of the [[Columbia River Plateau]], formed by basalt lava flows and water erosion, and is named after the [[Hanford Reach]], the last free flowing section of the [[Columbia River]].{{cite web|url=http://www.fws.gov/hanfordreach/|title=Hanford Reach National Monument|publisher=U.S. Fish & Wildlife Service|accessdate=2009-01-19}} |- | [[Harriet Tubman Underground Railroad National Monument|Harriet Tubman Underground Railroad]] | [[File:Stewart's Canal - Harriet Tubman Underground RR NM.JPG|200px]] | [[U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service|FWS]] | [[Maryland]] | {{dts|2013|3|25}} | {{convert| 480|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | [[Harriet Tubman]] was a famed conductor on the [[Underground Railroad]], leading dozens of slaves to freedom. This monument includes sites relating to Tubman's life, including the slave-built Stewart’s Canal and the home of Jacob Jackson. The areas within the national monument that are managed by the NPS have been additionally designated as a National Historical Park (NHP), and are managed by the NPS with reference to the authorities of the NHP legislation.{{cite web|url=https://www.fws.gov/uploadedFiles/Region_5/NWRS/South_Zone/Chesapeake_Marshlands_Complex/Blackwater/HTPartnersNewsletter_Dec14.pdf |title=Newsletter |website=www.fws.gov |format=PDF}} |- | [[Hohokam Pima National Monument|Hohokam Pima]] | [[File:Hohokam Pima National Monument.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[Arizona]]
{{coord|33.19|-111.91|name=Hohokam Pima|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1972|10|21}} | {{convert| 1690|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Hohokam Pima is part of the [[Gila River Indian Community]] and not open to the public. The monument preserves the [[Snaketown]]-Settlement, archeological remains of the [[Hohokam]] culture, which lived in the area until 1500.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/pima/|title=Hohokam Pima National Monument|date=June 15, 2007|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-19}} |- | [[Homestead National Monument of America|Homestead]] | [[File:Homestead Freeman School.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[Nebraska]]
{{coord|40.285|-96.822|name=Homestead|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1936|3|19}} | {{convert| 211.09|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | [[Daniel Freeman (homesteader)|Daniel Freeman]]'s homestead was recognized by the [[United States Congress]] as the first homestead in the nation obtained through the [[Homestead Act]] of 1862. The monument contains a visitor center, a tract of [[tallgrass prairie]], and the Freeman School.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/home/|title=Homestead National National Monument|date=January 2, 2009|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-19}} |- | [[Honouliuli Internment Camp|Honouliuli]] | [[File:Honouliuli Internment Camp.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[Hawaii]]
{{coord|21.392|-158.060|name=Honouliuli|type:landmark}} | {{dts|2015|2|19}} | {{convert| 154.46|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Comprises the grounds of the [[Honouliuli Internment Camp]] on the island of [[Oahu]]. It was the largest and longest-operating facility used for [[Japanese American internment]] in the United States.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/hono/historyculture/index.htm|title=Honouliuli National National Monument|date=February 19, 2015|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2015-02-15}} |- | [[Hovenweep National Monument|Hovenweep]] | [[File:Squaretower.JPG|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[Colorado]], [[Utah]]
{{coord|37.38|-109.08|name=Hovenweep|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1923|3|2}} | {{convert| 784.93|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Hovenweep contains six clusters of [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] ruins. Holly Canyon, Hackberry Canyon, Cutthroat Castle and [[Goodman Point]] are in Colorado and Square Tower and Cajon are in Utah. [[Ancient Pueblo Peoples]] lived in the Hovenweep area from 1150 to 1350.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/hove/|title=Hovenweep National National Monument|date=August 23, 2007|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-19}} |- | [[Ironwood Forest National Monument|Ironwood Forest]] | [[File:Ragged Top Ironwood Forest National Monument Arizona 2014.jpg|200px]] | [[Bureau of Land Management|BLM]] | [[Arizona]]
{{coord|32.46|-111.57|name=Ironwood Forest|type:landmark}} | {{dts|2000|6|9}} | {{convert| 129055|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Located within the [[Sonoran Desert]], significant concentrations of ironwood (''[[Olneya tesota]]'') trees and two [[endangered species|endangered]] animal and plant species are found within the monument. More than 200 [[Hohokam]] and Paleoindian archeological sites have been identified from between 600 and 1450 AD{{cite web|url=http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/fo/grand_staircase-escalante.html|title=Grand Staircase-Ironwood Forest National Monument|date=September 15, 2008|publisher=Bureau of Land Management|accessdate=2009-01-19|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090116120800/http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/fo/grand_staircase-escalante.html|archivedate=January 16, 2009|df=}} |- | [[Jewel Cave National Monument|Jewel Cave]] | [[File:JECA formations.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[South Dakota]]
{{coord|43.73|-103.83|name=Jewel Cave|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1908|2|7}} | {{convert| 1273.51|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Jewel Cave is the third longest [[cave]] in the world, with more than {{convert|195|mi|km}} of mapped passageways beneath the [[Black Hills]] of South Dakota.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/jeca/|title=Jewel Cave National Monument|date=March 18, 2018|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=May 29, 2018}} The entrance was discovered by miners in 1900 and was named for its [[calcite]] crystals.{{cite web|url=https://www.nps.gov/jeca/learn/historyculture/index.htm|title=Early Jewel Cave History|date=November 29, 2015|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=May 29, 2018}} |- | [[John Day Fossil Beds National Monument|John Day Fossil Beds]] | [[File:JOHNDAY.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[Oregon]]
{{coord|44.67|-120.05|name=John Day Fossil|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1974|10|26}} | {{convert| 14062.02|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Located within the [[John Day River]] Basin, the Fossil Beds have a well-preserved, complete record of [[fossil]] plants and animals from more than 40 of the 65 million years of the [[Cenozoic Era]]. The monument is divided into three units: [[Painted Hills]], named for its delicately colored [[Stratigraphy|stratifications]]; Sheep Rock; and Clarno. Blue Basin is a [[volcanic ash]] bowl transformed into claystone by eons of [[erosion]], colored pastel blue by [[mineral]]s.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/joda/|title=John Day Fossil Beds National Monument|date=December 29, 2007|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-19}} |- | [[Kasha-Katuwe Tent Rocks National Monument|Kasha-Katuwe Tent Rocks]] | [[File:Tent rocks MG 3183.jpg|200px]] | [[Bureau of Land Management|BLM]] | [[New Mexico]]
{{coord|35.67|-106.42|name=Kasha-Katuwe Tent Rocks|type:landmark}} | {{dts|2001|1|17}} | {{convert| 4647|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Kasha-Katuwe is known for its geology of layers of volcanic rock and ash deposited by a volcanic explosion. Over time, [[weathering]] and [[erosion]] of these layers has created canyons and [[tent rock]]s. The tent rocks themselves are cones of soft [[pumice]] and [[tuff]] beneath harder [[caprock]]s.{{cite web|url=http://www.blm.gov/nm/st/en/prog/recreation/rio_puerco/kasha_katuwe_tent_rocks.html|title=Kasha-Katuwe Tent Rocks National Monument|date=January 8, 2009|publisher=Bureau of Land Management|accessdate=2009-01-24|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090123104657/http://www.blm.gov/nm/st/en/prog/recreation/rio_puerco/kasha_katuwe_tent_rocks.html|archivedate=January 23, 2009|df=}} |- | [[Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument|Katahdin Woods and Waters]] | [[File:Katahdin, photographed from the Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument.png|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[Maine]]
{{coord|45.97|-68.62|name=Katahdin Woods and Waters|type:landmark}} | {{dts|2016|8|24}} | {{convert| 87564.27|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument covers 87,563 acres (35,435 ha) of mountains and wilderness in the North Maine Woods area of north-central Maine, including a section of the East Branch Penobscot River. It borders the eastern side of Baxter State Park in Penobscot County.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/kaww/|title=Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument|date=January 13, 2017|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2017-01-13}} |- | [[Lava Beds National Monument|Lava Beds]] | [[File:Lavacicles 8238.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[California]]
{{coord|41.71|-121.51|name=Lava Beds|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1925|11|21}} | {{convert| 46692.42|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | This is the site of the largest concentration of [[lava tube]] [[cave]]s in [[North America]]. It also includes Petroglyph Point, one of the largest panels of Native American rock art. The monument lies on the northeast flank of the [[Medicine Lake Volcano]], the largest volcano in the [[Cascade Range]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/labe/|title=Lava Beds National Monument|date=January 18, 2009|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-24}} |- | [[Little Bighorn Battlefield National Monument|Little Bighorn Battlefield]] | [[File:Little Bighorn memorial obelisk.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[Montana]]
{{coord|45.57|-107.43|name=Little Bighorn Battlefield|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1940|7|1}} | {{convert| 765.34|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | This monument includes the 1876 [[Battle of the Little Bighorn]] between [[George Armstrong Custer]]'s [[U.S. 7th Cavalry Regiment|7th Cavalry]] and a combined [[Lakota people|Lakota]]-[[Northern Cheyenne]] and [[Arapaho]] force, Custer National Cemetery, and the Reno-Benteen Battlefield.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/libi/|title=Little Bighorn Battlefield National Monument|date=August 23, 2007|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-24}} |- | [[Marianas Trench Marine National Monument|Marianas Trench Marine]] |
[[File:Marianatrenchmap.png|160px]]
| [[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|NOAA]], [[Fish and Wildlife Service|FWS]] | [[Northern Mariana Islands]], [[Guam]]
{{coord|20|145|name=Marianas Trench Marine|type:landmark}} | {{dts|2009|1|6}} | {{convert| 61077668|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Covering over {{convert|95000|mi2|km2}}, this marine monument includes the waters and submerged lands of the three northernmost islands of the [[Mariana Islands|Mariana Archipelago]], the submerged lands of 22 designated volcanic sites, and the [[Mariana Trench]].{{cite web|url=http://www.fws.gov/pacific/news/2009/monuments/TrenchMarine.pdf|title=Establishment of the Marianas Trench Marine National Monument|date=January 6, 2009|publisher=The White House: President George W. Bush|format=PDF|accessdate=2009-01-25}} |- | [[Military Working Dog Teams National Monument|Military Working Dog Teams]] |
[[File:Not Forgotten Fountain - Oct 28--2013.jpg|160px]]
| [[United States Department of Defense|DOD]] | [[Texas]]
{{coord|29.390|-98.617|name=Military Working Dog Teams National Monument|type:landmark}} | {{dts|2013|10|28}} | | The monument, located at [[Lackland Air Force Base]], the home of the [[U.S. Department of Defense]] Military Working Dog Program, honors the efforts and sacrifices of [[military working dogs]] in the service of the United States.{{cite web|url=http://www.jbmf.us/|title=John Burnam Memorial Foundation|date=October 28, 2013|publisher=John Burnam Memorial Foundation|accessdate=2015-04-20}} |- | [[Misty Fjords National Monument|Misty Fjords]] | [[File:Mifj inlet.jpg|200px]] | [[United States Forest Service|USFS]] | [[Alaska]]
{{coord|55.62|-130.61|name=Misty Fjords|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1978|12|1}} | {{convert| 2294072|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Located within the [[Tongass National Forest]] and called The [[Yosemite National Park|Yosemite]] of the North for its similar geology, it also contains the Quartz Hill [[molybdenum]] deposit, possibly the largest such mineral deposit in the world. Throughout the monument is light-colored [[granite]], about 50 to 70 million years old ([[Eocene Epoch]] to [[Cretaceous]] Period), that has been sculpted by [[glacier]]s that gouged deep U-shaped troughs. [[Mountain goats]] live in the higher elevations, while brown and black bear are also common.{{cite web|url=http://www.fs.fed.us/r10/tongass/forest_facts/resources/wilderness/misty.shtml|title=Misty Fiords National Monument|date=August 7, 2007|publisher=USDA Forest Service |accessdate=2009-01-24}} |- | [[Mojave Trails National Monument|Mojave Trails]] | [[File:Photo of Mojave Trails National Monument.jpg|200px]] | [[Bureau of Land Management|BLM]] | [[California]]
{{coord|34.6|-116.0|name=Mojave Trails|type:landmark}} | {{dts|2016|2|12}} | {{convert| 1600000|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Spanning 1.6 million acres, more than 350,000 acres of previously congressionally-designated Wilderness, the Mojave Trails National Monument comprises a stunning mosaic of rugged mountain ranges, ancient lava flows, and spectacular sand dunes. The monument will protect irreplaceable historic resources including ancient Native American trading routes, World War II-era training camps, and the longest remaining undeveloped stretch of Route 66.{{cite web|url=http://www.blm.gov/ca/st/en/prog/nlcs/Mojave_Trails.html|title=Mojave Trails National Monument|date=|publisher=Bureau of Land Management|accessdate=2016-02-12|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160216044509/http://www.blm.gov/ca/st/en/prog/nlcs/Mojave_Trails.html|archivedate=2016-02-16|df=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2016/02/12/fact-sheet-president-obama-designate-new-national-monuments-california|title=President Obama to Designate New National Monuments in the California Desert|date=2016-02-12|publisher=The White House|accessdate=2016-02-12}} |- | [[Montezuma Castle National Monument|Montezuma Castle]] | [[File:Montezuma Castle National Monument2.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[Arizona]]
{{coord|34.61|-111.84|name=Montezuma Castle|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1906|12|8}} | {{convert| 1015.52|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Montezuma Castle features [[cliff dwelling]]s built by the [[Pre-Columbian]] [[Sinagua]] people between 1100 and 1400 AD. The site's name is a misnomer as is it has no connection to [[Montezuma II|Montezuma]]. However, some modern day native tribes that do have connections to the site include the [[Yavapai]], [[Hopi]], and [[Zuni]]. The monument also includes [[Montezuma Well]], which has been used for irrigation since the 8th century.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/moca/|title=Montezuma Castle National Monument|date=|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-24}} |- | [[Mount St. Helens National Volcanic Monument|Mount St. Helens]] | [[File:MSH82 st helens plume from harrys ridge 05-19-82.jpg|200px]] | [[US Forest Service|USFS]] | [[Washington (U.S. state)|Washington]]
{{coord|46.23|-122.18|name=Mount St. Helens|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1982|8|27}} | {{convert| 113205|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Following the [[1980 eruption of Mount St. Helens|1980 eruption]] of the now-{{convert|8363|ft|m|-tall|adj=mid}} [[Mount St. Helens]], the environment was left to respond naturally to the disturbance. The volcanic crater is surrounded by a [[pumice]] plain with deposits from the landslide, wind-blown trees, and the [[Ape Cave]] [[lava tube]]. {{cite web|url=http://www.fs.fed.us/gpnf/mshnvm/|title=Mount St. Helens National Volcanic Monument|date=January 14, 2009|publisher=US Forest Service|accessdate=2009-01-24}} |- | [[Muir Woods National Monument|Muir Woods]] | [[File:MUWO4193.JPG|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[California]]
{{coord|37.89|-122.58|name=Muir Woods|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1908|1|9}} | {{convert| 553.55|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Part of the [[Golden Gate National Recreation Area]], it protects one of the last [[Old growth forest|old growth]] [[Coast redwood]] (''Sequoia sempervirens'') groves in the [[San Francisco Bay Area]] as well as one of the most easily accessed.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/muwo/|title=Muir Woods National Monument|date=December 30, 2008|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-24}} |- | [[Natural Bridges National Monument|Natural Bridges]] | [[File:Owachomo laban.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[Utah]]
{{coord|37.58|-110|name=Natural Bridges|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1908|4|16}} | {{convert| 7636.49|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Located at the junction of [[White Canyon]] and Armstrong Canyon, it is part of the [[Colorado River]] drainage. It features the second- and third-largest [[natural arch|natural bridges]] in the western hemisphere, carved from the white [[Triassic]] sandstone of the [[Cedar Mesa Sandstone|Cedar Mesa Formation]] that gives White Canyon its name.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/nabr/|title=Natural Bridges National Monument|date=|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-24}} |- | [[Navajo National Monument|Navajo]] | [[File:Keet Seel closeup.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[Arizona]]
{{coord|36.68|-110.53|name=Navajo|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1909|3|20}} | {{convert| 360|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | This monument preserves three of the most intact cliff dwellings of the [[Ancestral Puebloan]] people. The monument is high on the Shonto plateau, overlooking the Tsegi Canyon system on the Navajo Nation in Northern Arizona.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/nava/|title=Navajo National Monument|date=August 23, 2007|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-24}} |- | [[Newberry National Volcanic Monument|Newberry]] | [[File:Nebe caldera10832l.jpg|200px]] | [[US Forest Service|USFS]] | [[Oregon]]
{{coord|43.69|-121.25|name=Newberry Volcano|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1990|11|5}} | {{convert| 57323|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Located within [[Deschutes National Forest]], the monument protects the area around the [[Newberry Volcano]] and its geologic features. It contains over {{convert|50000|acre|km2}} of lakes, lava flows, and other geologic features.{{cite web|url=http://www.fs.fed.us/r6/centraloregon/newberrynvm/index.shtml|title=Newberry National Volcanic Monument|date=September 18, 2008|publisher=USDA Forest Service|accessdate=2009-01-24}} |- | [[Northeast Canyons and Seamounts Marine National Monument|Northeast Canyons and Seamounts Marine]] |
[[File:Northeast Canyons and Seamounts Marine National Monument map NOAA.png|160px]]
| [[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|NOAA]], [[U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service|FWS]] | [[Atlantic Ocean]]
{{coord|40.4|-68|name=Northeast Canyons and Seamounts Marine|type:landmark}} | {{dts|2016|09|15}} | {{convert| 3144320|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | The monument protects four underwater seamounts and three very deep canyons in the continental shelf {{convert|100|mi|km}} off the coast of Massachusetts, home to several endangered species.{{cite web|title=FACT SHEET: President Obama to Continue Global Leadership in Combatting Climate Change and Protecting Our Ocean by Creating the First Marine National Monument in the Atlantic Ocean|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2016/09/15/fact-sheet-president-obama-continue-global-leadership-combatting-climate|publisher=The White House|accessdate=19 September 2016}} |- | [[Ocmulgee National Monument|Ocmulgee]] | [[File:Macon Ocmulgee Earth Lodge.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]]
{{coord|32.83|-83.61|name=Ocmulgee|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1936|12|23}} | {{convert| 703.7|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Ocmulgee preserves traces of more than 10 millennia of native Southeastern culture, including [[Mississippian culture|Mississippian]] [[Mound builder (people)|mounds]]. From Ice Age hunters to the [[Creek (people)|Creek Indians]] of historic times, there is evidence of at least 10,000 years of human habitation. Between 900 and 1150, an elite society supported by skillful farmers lived on this site near the [[Ocmulgee River]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/ocmu/|title=Ocmulgee National Monument|date=|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-24}} |- | [[Oregon Caves National Monument|Oregon Caves]] | [[File:Oregon Caves p1080458 1024.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[Oregon]]
{{coord|42.10|-123.41|name=Oregon Caves|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1909|7|12}} | {{convert| 4554.03|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | The monument is known for its [[marble]] [[cave]]s, as well as for the [[Pleistocene]] [[jaguar]] and [[grizzly bear]] [[fossil]]s found in the deeper caves. There are four primary buildings: The [[Oregon Caves Chateau]], The Ranger Residence, The Chalet, and the old Dormitory.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/orca/|title=Oregon Caves National Monument|date=|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-24}} |- | [[Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument|Organ Pipe Cactus]] | [[File:Organ pipe cactus arches.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[Arizona]]
{{coord|32.04|-112.86|name=Organ Pipe Cactus|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1937|4|13}} | {{convert| 330688.86|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | This monument is the only place in the United States where the [[organ pipe cactus]] grows wild. There are many other types of [[cactus|cacti]] and desert flora native to the [[Sonoran Desert]]. The [[Bates Well Ranch]] and [[Dos Lomitas Ranch]] are also within the monument.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/orpi/|title=Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument|date=August 31, 2008|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-24}} |- | [[Organ Mountains-Desert Peaks National Monument|Organ Mountains-Desert Peaks]] | [[File:Organ Needle.jpg|200px]] | [[Bureau of Land Management|BLM]] | [[New Mexico]]
{{coord|32.3|-106.55|name=Organ Mountains-Desert Peaks|type:landmark}} | {{dts|2014|5|21}} | {{convert| 419532|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | The protected area includes five mountain ranges that rise above the [[Chihuahua Desert]]: [[Robledo Mountains]], [[Sierra de las Uvas]], [[Doña Ana Mountains]], [[Organ Mountains (New Mexico)|Organ Mountains]] and [[West Potrillo Mountains|Potrillo Mountains]]. There are approximately 870 vascular plant species, and the area is popular for hiking and climbing. |- | [[Pacific Remote Islands Marine National Monument|Pacific Remote Islands Marine]] | [[File:Howland Itascatown.jpg|200px]] | [[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|NOAA]], [[Fish and Wildlife Service|FWS]] | [[United States Minor Outlying Islands|US Minor Outlying Islands]] south-southwest of Hawaii
{{coord|16.75|-169.52|name=Pacific Remote Islands Marine|type:landmark}} | {{dts|2009|1|6}} | {{convert| 313941851|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | The marine monument consists of [[Baker Island]], [[Howland Island]], [[Jarvis Island]], [[Johnston Atoll]], [[Kingman Reef]], [[Palmyra Atoll]], and [[Wake Island]], which are in the [[Pacific]] southwest of Hawaii.{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/media/acrobat/2009-01/44374653.pdf|title=Marine National Monument maps|publisher=''L. A. Times''|format=PDF|accessdate=2009-01-25}} |- | [[Papahānaumokuākea Marine National Monument|Papahānaumokuākea Marine]] | [[File:Albatross birds at Northwest Hawaiian Islands National Monument, Midway Atoll, 2007March01.jpg|200px]] | [[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|NOAA]], [[U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service|FWS]] | [[Hawaii]], [[United States Minor Outlying Islands|U.S. Minor Outlying Islands]]
{{coord|25.7|-171.73|name=Papahānaumokuākea|type:landmark}} | {{dts|2006|6|15}} | {{convert| 372848597|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | The marine monument consists of ocean waters and 10 islands and atolls of the [[Northwestern Hawaiian Islands]] including [[Midway Atoll]] (which is the site of the [[Midway Atoll National Wildlife Refuge]]). The monument was created in 2006 with {{convert|139,797|mi2|km2}}, and its boundaries were expanded on August 26, 2016, more than quadrupling in size to a total area of {{convert|582,578|mi2|km2}}. It is the largest protected area on [[Earth]], and is almost the size of the [[Gulf of Mexico]].[http://www.papahanaumokuakea.gov/news/expansion_announcement.html President announces expansion of Papahānaumokuākea], National Ocean Service, Office of National Marine Sanctuaries, [[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]] (last revised August 26, 2016). The Northwestern Hawaiian Islands [[archipelago]] "is the planet's largest seabird gathering site, with more than 14 million birds from 22 species, and is home to nearly all [[Laysan albatross]]es and the remaining endangered [[Hawaiian monk seals]]."Juliet Eilperin, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/obama-to-create-the-largest-protected-place-on-the-planet-off-hawaii/2016/08/25/54ecb632-6aec-11e6-99bf-f0cf3a6449a6_story.html Obama creates the largest protected place on the planet, in Hawaii], ''Washington Post'' (August 26, 2016). It was declared a [[World Heritage Site]] in 2010.{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/news/640|title=UNESCO World Heritage Centre – World Heritage Committee inscribes two new sites on World Heritage List|publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|work=unesco.org|date=July 30, 2010|accessdate=April 5, 2018}} |- | [[Petroglyph National Monument|Petroglyph]] |
[[File:2004-05-06 07 - Petroglyph, NM.jpg|160px]]
| [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[New Mexico]]
{{coord|35.16|-106.76|name=Petroglyph|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1990|6|27}} | {{convert| 7209.3|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | This monument protects a variety of cultural and natural resources, including five [[volcanic cones]], hundreds of archeological sites and an estimated 25,000 images carved by native peoples and early Spanish settlers. It lies on [[West Mesa]], a [[volcanic]] [[basalt]] [[escarpment]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/petr/|title=Petroglyph National Monument|date=August 23, 2007|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-24}} |- | [[Pipe Spring National Monument|Pipe Spring]] | [[File:Pisp fort.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[Arizona]]
{{coord|36.86|-112.73|name=Pipe Spring|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1923|5|31}} | {{convert| 40|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Rich with [[Native Americans in the United States|Native Americans]], early explorer and [[Mormon pioneer]] history, this site shows [[Ancestral Puebloans]] and Kaibab [[Southern Paiute|Paiute]] Indian and [[settler|pioneer]] life in the [[Old West]], including the cabin where explorer [[John Wesley Powell]]'s survey crew stayed in 1871. The water of Pipe Spring, discovered in 1858, made it possible for plants, animals, and people to live in this dry desert region.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/pisp/|title=Pipe Spring National Monument|date=August 23, 2007|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-24}} |- | [[Pipestone National Monument|Pipestone]] | [[File:Pipe quarry 01.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[Minnesota]]
{{coord|44.01|-96.33|name=Pipestone|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1937|8|25}} | {{convert| 281.78|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | This monument preserves traditional [[catlinite]] [[quarry|quarries]] used to make [[ceremonial pipe]]s, vitally important to traditional [[Plains Indians|Plains Indian]] culture. The quarries are sacred to the [[Sioux]] and [[Lakota people]] and are historically neutral territory where enrolled citizens of all tribes can quarry the stone.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/pipe/|title=Pipestone National Monument|date=March 28, 2008|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-24}} |- | [[Pompeys Pillar National Monument|Pompeys Pillar]] | [[File:Pompeys pillar boardwalk.jpg|200px]] | [[Bureau of Land Management|BLM]] | [[Montana]]
{{coord|45.99|-108.001|name=Pompeys Pillar|type:landmark}} | {{dts|2001|01|17}} | {{convert| 51|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Pompeys Pillar is a {{convert|150|ft|m|adj=on}} [[sandstone]] pillar from the late [[Cretaceous]] [[Hell Creek Formation]] next to the [[Yellowstone River]]. It has an abundance of [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] [[petroglyph]]s, as well as the signature of [[William Clark (explorer)|William Clark]], who named the formation after [[Sacagawea]]'s infant son.{{cite web|url=http://www.blm.gov/mt/st/en/fo/billings_field_office/Pompeys_Pillar.html|title=Welcome to Pompeys Pillar National Monument|date=January 5, 2009|publisher=Bureau of Land Management|accessdate=2009-01-24|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090131203911/http://www.blm.gov/mt/st/en/fo/billings_field_office/Pompeys_Pillar.html|archivedate=January 31, 2009|df=}} |- | [[Poverty Point National Monument|Poverty Point]] |
[[File:Poverty point 1938 USACE-3.jpg|160px]]
| [[National Park Service|NPS]]As of 2009, Poverty Point is a public park owned and operated by the state of Louisiana. See [[Poverty Point#History]] | [[Louisiana]]
{{coord|32.63|-91.41|name=Poverty Point|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1988|10|31}} | {{convert| 910.85|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Poverty Point is a prehistoric archeological site that dates from between 1650 and 700 BC and consisting of six earthen rings and seven mounds. The diameter of the outside ridge is {{convert|0.75|mi|km}}, and the largest mound rises {{convert|51|ft|m}}.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/popo/|title=Poverty Point National Monument|date=April 14, 2008|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-24}} It was declared a [[World Heritage Site]] in 2014.{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/news/1162|title=Twenty six new properties added to World Heritage List at Doha meeting|publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|work=unesco.org|date=June 25, 2014|accessdate=April 5, 2018}} |- | [[Prehistoric Trackways National Monument|Prehistoric Trackways]] | [[File:Prehistoric-trackways-01.gif|200px]] | [[Bureau of Land Management|BLM]] | [[New Mexico]]
{{coord|32.35|-106.9|name=Prehistoric Trackways|type:landmark}} | {{dts|2009|03|30}} | {{convert| 5280|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Prehistoric Trackways contains fossilized footprints of numerous Paleozoic amphibians, reptiles, and insects, as well as fossilized plants and petrified wood dating back approximately 280 million years. (Public Law No. 111-11) |- | [[President Lincoln and Soldiers’ Home National Monument|President Lincoln and Soldiers’ Home]] | [[File:Lincoln Cottage 2007.jpg|200px]] | [[Armed Forces Retirement Home|AFRH]] | [[District of Columbia]]
{{coord|38.9416|-77.0117|name=President Lincoln and Soldiers' Home|type:landmark}} | {{dts|2000|7|7}} | {{convert| 2.3|acre|km2|2|sortable=on}}{{cite web |url=https://clintonwhitehouse4.archives.gov/CEQ/proclamation.html |title=President Lincoln and Soldiers' Home National Monument |last=Clinton |first=William |date=July 7, 2000 |website=clintonwhitehouse4.archives.gov |publisher=[[White House Office of the Press Secretary]]|location=Washington, D.C. |access-date=Feb 13, 2018 |quote=}} | President Abraham Lincoln and his family resided seasonally on the grounds of the Armed Forces Retirement Home, which was founded in 1851 for homeless and disabled war veterans. The national monument and adjacent visitor center are preserved and operated by President Lincoln’s Cottage at the Soldiers’ Home, a 501(c)(3) public charity, on behalf of the Armed Forces Retirement Home.{{cite web|url=http://www.lincolncottage.org/about/|title=President Lincoln's Cottage at the Soldiers' Home|publisher=President Lincoln's Cottage at the Soldiers' Home|accessdate=2016-05-18}} |- | [[Pullman National Monument|Pullman]] |
[[File:Pullman Chicago Clock Tower.jpg|160px]]
| [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[Illinois]]
{{coord|41.691|-87.610|name=Pullman National Monument|type:landmark}} | {{dts|2015|2|19}} | {{convert| 0.4|acre|km2|3|sortable=on}} | Built for the [[Pullman Company]], it was the first planned industrial community in the United States and the site of the 1894 [[Pullman Strike]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/pull/|title=Pullman National Monument|date=|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2017-01-13}} |- | [[Rainbow Bridge National Monument|Rainbow Bridge]] | [[File:Utah Rainbow Arch.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[Utah]]
{{coord|37.08|-110.96|name=Rainbow Bridge|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1910|5|30}} | {{convert| 160|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Rainbow Bridge is one of the world's largest [[natural bridge]]s. It stands {{convert|290|ft|m}} tall and spans {{convert|275|ft|m}} wide; the top of the bridge is {{convert|42|ft|m}} thick and {{convert|33|ft|m}} wide. It was made from [[sandstone]] formed during the [[Triassic]] and the [[Jurassic]] periods.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/rabr/|title=Rainbow Bridge National Monument|date=|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-24}} |- |[[Reconstruction Era National Monument|Reconstruction Era]] |[[File:The Firehouse (5555968332).jpg|200px]] |[[National Park Service|NPS]] |[[South Carolina]]
{{coord|32|25|57|N|80|40|14|W|name=Reconstruction Era|type:landmark}} |{{dts|2017|1|12}} | {{convert| 15.53|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} |Preserves four locations in and near [[Beaufort, South Carolina]]—a school, church, firehouse, and the [[Camp Saxton Site]]—to commemorate activities during the [[Reconstruction era]] that followed the [[American Civil War]].{{cite web|url=https://www.nps.gov/reer/learn/proclamation.htm|title=Presidential Proclamation - Reconstruction Era National Monument|date=January 13, 2017|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=November 4, 2018}} |- | [[Río Grande del Norte National Monument|Río Grande del Norte]] | [[File:Rio Grande Gorge pano.jpg|200px]] | [[Bureau of Land Management|BLM]] | [[New Mexico]]
{{coord|36.66667|-105.7|name=Rio Grande del Norte|type:landmark}} | {{dts|2013|3|25}} | {{convert| 242710|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | This site includes part of the [[Rio Grande Gorge]] and extinct volcanoes of the [[Taos Plateau volcanic field]]. There are a variety of archaeological and historical artifacts including petroglyphs and Hispanic settlement sites. It is home to an assortment of wildlife and recreation opportunities. |- | [[Rose Atoll Marine National Monument|Rose Atoll Marine]] | [[File:Nwrroseatollside320.gif|200px]] | [[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|NOAA]], [[Fish and Wildlife Service|FWS]] | [[American Samoa]]
{{Coord|-14.55|-168.54|name=Rose Atoll Marine |region:US-AS_type:landmark}} | {{dts|2009|1|6}} | {{convert| 8609045|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | This marine monument consists of the two small islands of [[Rose Atoll]], a lagoon, and a coral reef east of American Samoa. It is the [[Extreme points of the United States|southernmost point in the U.S.]].{{cite web |url=http://www.fws.gov/pacific/news/2009/Monuments/roseatoll.pdf |format=PDF|title=Establishment of the Rose Atoll Marine National Monument|date=January 6, 2009|publisher=The White House: President George W. Bush|accessdate=2009-01-25}} |- | [[Russell Cave National Monument|Russell Cave]] | [[File:Russell Cave.JPG|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[Alabama]]
{{coord|34.97|-85.80|name=Russell Cave|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1961|5|11}} | {{convert| 310.45|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Donated by the [[National Geographic Society]], the cave's exceptionally large main entrance was used as a shelter by [[prehistory|prehistoric]] Indians from the earliest known human settlement in the southeastern United States. The rock from which Russell Cave was formed over 300 million years ago at the bottom of an inland sea that covered the region.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/ruca/|title=Russell Cave National Monument|date=|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-24}} |- | [[Salinas Pueblo Missions National Monument|Salinas Pueblo Missions]] | [[File:Salinas Pueblo Missions National Monument ruins.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[New Mexico]]
{{coord|34.26|-106.06|name=Salinas Pueblo Missions|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1909|11|1}} | {{convert| 1071.42|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Formerly known as Gran Quivira National Monument, it is where [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] trade communities of Tiwa- and Tompiro-speaking [[Puebloan peoples|Puebloans]] lived when Spanish [[Franciscan]] missionaries made contact in the 17th century. What remains are the ruins of four mission churches, at Quarai, Abó, and Gran Quivira, and the partially excavated pueblo of Las Humanas.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/sapu/|title=Salinas Pueblo Missions National Monument|date= |publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-24}} |- | [[San Gabriel Mountains National Monument|San Gabriel Mountains]] | [[File:Throop Peak Mount Hawkins 033.jpg|200px]] | [[US Forest Service|USFS]] | [[California]]
{{coord|34.22|-118.06|name=San Gabriel Mountains|type:landmark}} | {{dts|2014|10|10}} | {{convert| 345222|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Covering 346,177 acres of the [[San Gabriel mountains]] in northern [[Los Angeles County, California|Los Angeles County]] and western [[San Bernardino County, California]], with peaks as high as {{convert|10068|ft|m|abbr=on}}, the San Gabriel Mountains provide one of the few open-space recreation opportunities close to residents of [[Los Angeles County]] and is also an important [[Drainage basin|watershed]] for the [[Los Angeles]] area.{{cite web|title=President Obama Designates San Gabriel Mountains National Monument|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2014/10/10/president-obama-designates-san-gabriel-mountains-national-monument|publisher=The White House|accessdate=10 October 2014}} |- | [[San Juan Islands National Monument|San Juan Islands]] | [[File:Iceberg Point Lopez Island Washington USA.jpeg|200px]] | [[Bureau of Land Management|BLM]] | [[Washington (U.S. state)|Washington]]
{{coord|48.53|-123.03|name=San Juan Islands|type:landmark}} | {{dts|2013|3|25}} | {{convert| 970|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | The [[San Juan Islands]] in [[Puget Sound]] have several historic lighthouses as well as rugged landscapes. They are the habitat for orcas, eagles, and seals and provide opportunities for kayaking, birdwatching, and other activities. |- | [[Sand to Snow National Monument|Sand to Snow]] | [[File:Sand to Snow National Monument.jpg|200px]] | [[Bureau of Land Management|BLM]], [[US Forest Service|USFS]] | [[California]]
{{coord|34.08|-116.68|name=Sand to Snow|type:landmark}} | {{dts|2016|2|12}} | {{convert| 154000|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | The 154,000-acre monument extends from Bureau of Land Management lands on the Sonoran desert floor up to over 10,000 feet in the San Gorgonio Wilderness on the San Bernardino National Forest.{{cite web|url=http://www.fs.fed.us/visit/sand-to-snow-national-monument|title=Sand to Snow National Monument|date=2016-02-12|publisher=US Forest Service|accessdate=2016-02-12}} |- | [[Santa Rosa and San Jacinto Mountains National Monument|Santa Rosa and San Jacinto Mountains]] | [[File:Santa Rosa and San Jacinto Mountains 283.jpg|200px]] | [[Bureau of Land Management|BLM]], [[US Forest Service|USFS]] | [[California]]
{{coord|33.80|-116.70|name=Santa Rosa and San Jacinto Mountains|type:landmark}} | {{dts|2000|10|24}} | {{convert| 280009|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | This monument preserves large portions of the [[Santa Rosa Mountains (California)|Santa Rosa]] and [[San Jacinto Mountains|San Jacinto]] ranges, the northernmost of the [[Peninsular Ranges]]. Parts are within [[San Bernardino National Forest]] and the California Desert Conservation Area.{{cite web|url=http://www.blm.gov/ca/st/en/fo/palmsprings/santarosa.html|title=Santa Rosa and San Jacinto Mountains National Monument|date=October 31, 2008|publisher=Bureau of Land Management|accessdate=2009-01-24|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090126023854/http://www.blm.gov/ca/st/en/fo/palmsprings/santarosa.html|archivedate=January 26, 2009|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.fs.fed.us/r5/business-plans/san-bernardino/financials/monument.html|title=Santa Rosa/San Jacinto Mountains National Monument|publisher=USDA Forest Service|accessdate=2009-01-24}} |- | [[Scotts Bluff National Monument|Scotts Bluff]] | [[File:Saddlerock Scotts-Bluff NM Nebraska USA.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[Nebraska]]
{{coord|41.83|-103.70|name=Scotts Bluff|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1919|12|12}} | {{convert| 3004.73|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Scotts Bluff is an important 19th century geologic formation and landmark on the [[Oregon Trail]] and [[Mormon Pioneer National Historic Trail|Mormon Trail]]. It contains multiple bluffs on the south side of the [[North Platte River]], but it is named after a prominent bluff called Scotts Bluff which rises more than {{convert|830|ft|m}} above the plains at its highest point. The monument is composed of five rock formations named Crown Rock, Dome Rock, Eagle Rock, Saddle Rock, and Sentinel Rock.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/scbl/|title=Scotts Bluff National Monument|date=August 23, 2007|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-24}} |- | [[Sonoran Desert National Monument|Sonoran Desert]] | [[File:Son des 52697.jpg|200px]] | [[Bureau of Land Management|BLM]] | [[Arizona]]
{{coord|33.00|-112.46|name=Sonoran Desert|type:landmark}} | {{dts|2001|1|17}} | {{convert| 486400|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | This monument protects a small portion of the [[Sonoran Desert]]. It is home to several federally listed endangered species and also has three wilderness areas, many significant archeological and historic sites, and remnants of several important historic trails.{{cite web|url=http://www.blm.gov/az/st/en/prog/blm_special_areas/natmon/son_des.html|title=Sonoran Desert National Monument|date=January 5, 2009|publisher=Bureau of Land Management|accessdate=2009-01-24|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090126014634/http://www.blm.gov/az/st/en/prog/blm_special_areas/natmon/son_des.html|archivedate=January 26, 2009|df=}} |- | [[Statue of Liberty National Monument|Statue of Liberty]] | [[File:Statue of Liberty, NY.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[New York (state)|New York]], [[New Jersey]]
{{coord|40.69|-74.04|name=Statue of Liberty|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1924|10|15}} | {{convert| 58.38|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | This iconic statue, built in 1886 on [[Liberty Island]] and {{convert|151|ft|m}} tall, commemorates the centennial of the signing of the [[United States Declaration of Independence]] and is a gesture of friendship from France to the U.S. ''Liberty Enlightening the World'' is a symbol of welcoming immigrants to the U.S. and is listed as a [[World Heritage Site]]. [[Ellis Island]], where 12 million immigrants entering the U.S. passed through, is included in the monument.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/stli/|title=Statue of Liberty National Monument|date=|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-01-24}} |- | [[Stonewall National Monument|Stonewall]] | [[File:Stonewall Inn 2012 with gay-pride flags and banner.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[New York (state)|New York]]
{{coord|40.73364|-74.00212|name=Stonewall|type:landmark}} | {{dts|2016|06|24}} | {{convert| 7.7|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | The [[Stonewall Inn]], often shortened to Stonewall, is a gay bar and recreational tavern in [[New York City]] and the site of the [[Stonewall riots]] of 1969, which is widely considered to be the single most important event leading to the [[gay liberation]] movement and the modern fight for [[LGBT]] rights in the United States. Also included in the 7.7 acre site is [[Christopher Street Park]], across [[Christopher Street|the street]].[https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2016/06/24/president-obama-designates-stonewall-national-monument "President Obama Designates Stonewall National Monument"] (official announcement from White House Press Office; June 24, 2016) |- | [[Sunset Crater|Sunset Crater Volcano]] | [[File:SUCR2262.jpg|200px]] | [[National Park Service|NPS]] | [[Arizona]]
{{coord|35.36|-111.50|name=Sunset Crater Volcano|type:landmark}} | {{dts|1930|5|30}} | {{convert| 3040|acre|km2|1|sortable=on}} | Sunset Crater is the youngest in a string of volcanoes in the [[San Francisco volcanic field]] that is related to the nearby [[San Francisco Peaks]].
